argument.p: The ≈øhort Reign, and woful Death of Baldwin the Fifth. Guy ≈øucceeds him. Tripoli revolts. The Chri≈øtians overthrown. Their King taken Pri≈øoner. And the City of Jeru≈øalem won by the Turks.

div.p: IT hath ever been accounted one of the greate≈øt happine≈ø≈øes that can befal a Family, for the Heirs to be of Age before their Fathers death, in regard Minors have not only been the Ruine of Families, but the overthrow of Kingdoms too. Now the Earl of Tripoli demanding to be Protector of this young King, according

Whil≈øt Heraclius was Patriarch of Jeru≈øalem, one Hymericus injoyed that honour at Antioch, who wrote a bemoaning Letter to Henry the Second of England, wherein he much lamented the woful ≈øtate of the Chri≈øtians in the Ea≈øt, and endeavoured to per≈øuade that Prince to undertake a Voyage into Pale≈øtine for their

But be≈øides tho≈øe Latine Patriarchs which commanded in the Churches of Jeru≈øalem and Antioch, there were Grecian Anti-Patriarchs, who were appointed by the Emperour of Con≈øtantinople, and having no temporal Power nor Juri≈ødiction over the Latines, nor Profits of Church-Lands, were forced to content them≈øelves with a Juri≈ødiction over tho≈øe of the Greek Church only. And about this time we light on three that enjoyed that titular Dignity ≈øucce≈ø≈øively one after another; the fir≈øt whereof was Athana≈øius, who was (notwith≈øtanding his being called Schi≈ømatick by ≈øome of the Hi≈øtorians of that Age) a very learned and pious Man, as appears by the many excellent Epi≈øtles which he wrote upon ≈øeveral occa≈øions. There being about this time a Truce between the Turks and Chri≈øtians, and Saladine's Mother, ≈øuppo≈øing her ≈øelf ≈øufficiently guarded thereby, adventuring to travel from Egypt to Dama≈øcus, with abundance of Trea≈øure, and a very ≈ømall Train, ≈øhe was, notwith≈øtanding the Truce, ≈øurprized, and riffled of all ≈øhe had by Reinold of Ca≈øtile, which ba≈øe and unchri≈øtian act ≈øo inraged Saladine, that gathering together all his ≈øtrength, he immediately be≈øieged Ptolemais. Saladine having obtained this Victory, improved it ≈øo well, that in one months time he conquered Berytus, Biblus, Ptolemais,
and all the Havens except Ayre fro ‚Ä¢
Sidon to Askelon. He u≈øed his Conque ‚Ä¢ with great moderation, giving life an ‚Ä¢ goods to all, and forcing no Chri≈øtians „Äà‚óä„Äâ quit their habitations, ≈øave only the L ‚Ä¢

div.head: CHAP. XIX.

argument.p: Conrade Valiantly defending Tyre, is cho≈øen King. The Voyage of Frederick Emperor of Germany to the Holy Land. The Siege of Ptolemais. The Voyage of Richard King of England, and Philip King of France to the Holy Land.

div.p:
IN this ≈øad & deplorable State, ≈øtood the affairs in Pale≈øtine, when Conrade arrived there; who≈øe Worth and Excellence commands my Pen to attend him from his own Country thither. He was Son to Boniface Marque≈øs of Montferrat, who was taken Pri≈øoner in that Fatal Battle wherein King Guy lo≈øt him≈øelf and his Kingdom. His Youth was for the mo≈øt part ≈øpent in the Service of I≈øaaccius Angelus the Grecian Emperour; who being bred in a Mona≈øtery, the confining of his Body ≈øeemed to have brought him to a pent and narrow Soul, and indued him with Accompli≈øhments more becoming a Prie≈øt than a Prince: For when his Rebellious Subjects affronted him to the face, in≈øtead of ≈øending an Army again≈øt them, to reduce them to their obedience he only committed his cau≈øe to a company
of Bald-pated Friers, whom he kept in his Court, to pray for his Pro≈øperity; Hoping that, by their ≈øuppo≈øed Pious Tears, he ≈øhould be able to quench the Combu≈øtions of his Empire. But this Conrade told him plainly, that if ever he intended to ≈øit upon the Imperial Throne in Peace, he mu≈øt make u≈øe of the Weapons of the left Hand, as well as tho≈øe of the right, and Fight as well as Pray. Which advice being taken by the Emperour, he did, by the help of this General, quickly ≈øubdue all his Enemies: But our brave Conrade found but a ≈ømall reward for ≈øo great a ≈øervice, being only graced, in con≈øideration thereof, to wear his Shoes of the Imperial Fa≈øhion; And it being u≈øual with Princes, not to love the ≈øight of tho≈øe to whom they know them≈øelves obliged, and yet care not to reward, I≈øaaccius, by the per≈øwa≈øion of ≈øome about him, who envied his Courage and Bravery, ≈øpurred on Conrade, who was free enough of him≈øelf to any Noble Enterprize, to go into Pale≈øtine, and endeavour to ≈øupport the ruinous affairs of the afflicted Chri≈øtians. And although he was ≈øen≈øible of their Plot yet, being weary of the Grecians ba≈øene≈øs, he ≈øuffered him≈øelf to be prevailed upon to undertake that Honourable Imployment, and therefore ≈øet forward,
with all convenient ≈øpeed, for the Holy Land, with a gallant Band of Gentlemen, who fitted out them≈øelves at their own charge, wherewith he marched to the City of Tyre, where we will leave him for the pre≈øent, to return again to Saladine.

Who having won the City, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of the greate≈øt part of the Kingdom of Jeru≈øalem, laid clo≈øe Siege to the City of Askelon, which had refu≈øed to ≈øurrender, when Ptolemais and the re≈øt yielded to his victorious Arms; but was now, after a ≈øhort Siege, delivered to him, upon condition that King Guy & Gerard, Ma≈øters of the Templars, ≈øhould be ≈øett at Liberty And ≈øhortly after the Ca≈øtle of Antioch was betrayed to him by the Patriarch: And Antioch it ≈øelf, which co≈øt the Chri≈øtians 11 Months Siege was by that means lo≈øt in an in≈øtant, be≈øides ≈øeveral Provinces thereunto belonging, & Five & Twenty ≈øtrong Towns more, which followed the like Fate with Antioch, and fell into the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Turks. After which he ≈øat down likewi≈øe before Tripoli, but that City being, after the death of Earl Reimond, delivered to the Chri≈øtians by his Wife, they Bravely defended it again≈øt all Saladines Force, ≈øo that having once ta≈øted of their Valour in Tripoli he
had no great Stomach to make a ≈øecond trial, but rai≈øed his Siege, and marched away to Tyre, where he hoped to ≈øpeed better. But he found him≈øelf greatly mi≈øtaken, for Conrade being a little before got thither with his Army, gave him ≈øo hot a Welcome that he was glad to fly, and leave all his Tents behind him, which were ≈øufficiently lined with Trea≈øure, whereby the Chri≈øtians had the happine≈øs to inrich them≈øelves with their own Spoil.

Tho≈øe in the City over-joyed at their great deliverance, cho≈øe Conrade to be King of Jeru≈øalem, ≈øwearing Fealty to him, and promi≈øing to be for ever his Subjects, who≈øe Valour had pre≈øerved them from being Saladines Slaves. And the better to ≈øtrengthen his Title he married Eli≈øa, or, as others call her, I≈øabella, Si≈øter to Baldwin the fourth, and Daughter to King Almerick.

So that King Guy, who was about this time delivered out of Pri≈øon having, when he was relea≈øed, ≈øworn never more to bear Arms again≈øt Saladine (which Oath the Clergy judged void, becau≈øe forced from him when detained in Pri≈øon contrary to promi≈øe) obtained his Liberty, but could not get his Kingdom: For coming to Tyre, he found the Gates ≈øhut again≈øt him, and his Subjects refu≈øing to
acknowledge any other King then Conrade. Whereupon Guy, packing up a Cloth of Remnants, with his broken Army, went and be≈øieged Ptolemais, the Pi≈øans, Venetians, and Florentines, with their Sea-Forces, a≈ø≈øi≈øting him therein; But it went on notwith≈øtanding ≈øo ≈ølowly, that it could hardly be perceived to have made any advance in a Twelve Months time.

Things going thus wofully to wrack in Pale≈øtine, the Chri≈øtians ≈øighs there alarmed their Brethren in Europe, to repair thither to their Succour, and among the re≈øt Frederick Barbaro≈ø≈øa, Emperour of Germany, moved by the ≈øtrength of his Devotion, undertook a Voyage thither, when he was Seventy Years old, having one foot in the Grave, and yet adventureing, with the other, to go on Pilgrimage. He had been long chained to the Stake, as it were, and baited by ≈øeveral ≈øucce≈ø≈øive Popes, till at length wearied with their continual worrying of him, he gave up him≈øelf wholly to their direction, and was ≈øent by Pope Clement the third, on this Errand into the Holy Land.

And having made great Preparations for this Adventure, he marched through Hungary, with a gallant Army of an Hundred and Fifty Thou≈øand Valiant Men, being kindly received and Welcomed
by King Bela. But changing his Ho≈øt, he changed his Entertainment to being ba≈øely u≈øed as he pa≈ø≈øed through the Grecian Empire: In≈øomuch that Frederick, contrary to his expectation, finding ≈øuch perfidious dealing from the Greeks, drew his Sword, and re≈øolving to fight his way through, took Philippople, Adrianople, and divers other Citys, not ≈øo much to get their Spoil, as to ≈øecure his pa≈ø≈øage toward Pale≈øtine. But when I≈øaaccius ≈øaw that tho≈øe Pilgrims would either find or force their pa≈ø≈øage, he left off all terms of Enmity, and pre≈øently accommodated them with all things nece≈ø≈øary for their Tran≈øportation over the Bo≈øphorus, pretending to ha≈øten them away, becau≈øe the Chri≈øtians Exigencies in Pale≈øtine admitted of no delay; although it was really the effect of his fear, the Greeks ever loving the Latin, be≈øt when they were furthe≈øt off.

Old Frederick, having now left the treacherous Grecian Shore, and entred into the Turki≈øh Territories, found great re≈øi≈øtance from the Sultan of Iconium, whom he vanqui≈øhed, and overcame in four ≈øeveral Battles; And then, be≈øieging the City of Iconium, he took it by force and gave the Spoil of it to his Souldiers, to revenge the injury done by that Sultan
to his Uncle Conrade the Emperour: And removing from thence to Philomela, he took that likewi≈øe, razing it to the ground, and executing the Inhabitants therein, as Rebels again≈øt the Law of Nations, for killing his Amba≈ø≈øadors; after which he pa≈ø≈øed with much difficulty, but more honour, into Syria.

Saladine ≈øhook for fear at the rumor of his coming, and thought it be≈øt to follow the advice of Charatux, his chief Coun≈øellor, who was at that time accounted one of the wi≈øe≈øt men in the world, tho his Per≈øon was mean and contemptible, and di≈ømantled all his Citys, in the Holy Land, except his Frontire Towns that ≈øo they might not be tenable with an Army, fearing le≈øt, if the Germans won tho≈øe places, it would be no ea≈øy matter to drive them out again, but being naked from ≈øhelter, he thought he ≈øhould ≈øoon weary them with ≈øet Battles, in regard he had Soldiers without number, and tho≈øe near at hand.

But Frederick, ≈øoon after he was entered into the Holy Land, was ≈øuddenly taken away being, to the great grief of all Chri≈øtians, unhappily drowned in the River of Saleph; the occa≈øion whereof is variou≈øly reported by Hi≈øtorians, but they all agree that there he lo≈øt his Life, and
≈øome of them, pretending to acquaint the World with the rea≈øon why the Almighty permitted this Fatal Accident, tell us, that it was becau≈øe he had, in his Younger Years, fought again≈øt the Popes, and Church of Rome: But ≈øeeing ≈øo great an Emperour drowned in a ≈øhallow River, it was a great piece of audacious boldne≈øs in them, to adventure into the fathomle≈øs depths of Gods ≈øecret Council: Let it ≈øuffice therefore for us to know that he who di≈øpo≈øes of all humane affairs, according to his own Arbitrary Plea≈øure, ≈øometimes bla≈øts the faire≈øt hopes, and makes the Feet of Monarchs to ≈ølip, ju≈øt when they are ≈øtepping into their Enemies Throne.

After his death Frederick Duke of Su ‚Ä¢ via, his ≈øecond Son, undertook the conduct of the Army, when the Turks, ≈øuppo≈øing that grief for the lo≈øs of the Emperor had ≈øteeped, and moi≈øtened tho≈øe Pilgrims Hearts, and taken off the edg of their Valour, gave them a ≈øudden charge, in hope to have overthrown them before they had recovered them≈øelves; But the Valiant Dutch-men, though they had ≈øcarce wiped their Eyes, had however ≈øufficiently ≈øcowred their Swords, and gave them ≈øo warm a welcom that they quickly forced
them to retire. Then Frederick ≈øummoning the City of Antioch, had it pre≈øently delivered to him, where his hungry Souldiers being well refre≈øhed by the Citizens who were yet for the mo≈øt part Chri≈øtians, he marched forth in Battle Array, and meeting with Dodequin, General of Saladines forces, he gave him a mighty overthrow, wherein he ≈ølew four thou≈øand upon the place, and took a thou≈øand Turks Pri≈øoners, with little or no lo≈øs to him≈øelf. After which he went to the City of Tyre, in the Cathedral Church whereof he buried the Corps of his worthy and warlike Father, near the Tomb of the Learned Origen: His Funeral Sermon being preached by the worthy Arch-bi≈øhop Gulielmus of Tyre.

So ≈øoon as the Emperors Funeral Rites were ≈øolemnly performed, they were conveyed by Sea to the Chri≈øtian Army before Ptolemais, where young Frederick died of the Plague, and all his huge Army, which at their ≈øetting out of Germany con≈øi≈øted of an hundred and fifty thou≈øand men, were now reduced to eighteen hundred onely

And thus, by following this numerous Army to their graves, we have once again overtaken the tedious and ≈ølow-paced ≈øiege of Ptolemais, before which place
lay an Army that was, as it were, the abridgment of the Chri≈øtian World, there being ≈øcarce a petty ≈øtate or populous City in Europe, that had not ≈øome repre≈øentatitives there. So that there were many bloody Blowes lent on both ≈øides, & repayed again with intere≈øt in innumerable Sallys, fierce A≈ø≈øaults, and bloody Encounters. The Chri≈øtians lying between Saladine and the City were be≈øieged them≈øelves, whil≈øt they be≈øieged Ptolemais. It was at la≈øt propo≈øed by Saladine, that both ≈øides ≈øhould try their fortune in the field, which was ea≈øily a≈ø≈øented to by the Chri≈øtians, in hopes that they ≈øhould thereby both obtain the victory and win the City, which they concluded would not hold out long, if Saladine were beaten. But when they were going to ingage, an imaginary fear ≈øuddenly ≈øeizing them, they all turned their backs and fled; So wavering are the Scales of Victory, that ≈øometimes the lea≈øt mote will turn them. In which confu≈øion many would have thought them≈øelves happy if they could have exchanged a ≈øtrong Hand, for a ≈øwift Foot. But Geoffrey Lu≈øignan, Brother to King Guy, who was left to guard the Camp, ≈øeeing the Chri≈øtians ≈øhamefully to run away, marched out with his men to meet them, and having convinced them of
the cau≈øele≈øsne≈øs of their fear, and prevailed with them to return again, they ≈øet upon the Turks with ≈øo much fiercene≈øs and rage, that they quickly won the day, though it co≈øt them the lo≈øs of two thou≈øand men, and Gerard Ma≈øter of the Templars.

After this victory it was vainly expected by the Chri≈øtians, that the City would pre≈øently be ≈øurrendred to them, but the Turks ≈øtill continued to defend it with much re≈øolution, though mo≈øt of their hou≈øes were already burnt, or beaten down, and the whole City reduced to a perfect Sceleton of Walls and Towers. They fought with their wits as well as with their weapons, & both ≈øides employed them≈øelves in devi≈øing ≈øtrange & hitherto unknown offen≈øive & defen≈øive Engines: So that Mars him≈øelf, had he re≈øided either in that Camp or City, might have learnt to fight and have informed him≈øelf in feats of war, from their practice. At this time under the Walls of Ptolemais the Teutonick order of Dutch Knights, who had hitherto lived as private pilgrims, were honoured with a Grand Ma≈øter, & their „Äà2 pages missing„Äâ
were di≈øpen≈øed with by the Bi≈øhop of Rome. Mo≈øt of his Forces he ≈øent about by Spain, but went him≈øelf and ≈øome few of his friends through France, having his Pilgrims ≈øcrip and ≈øtaff delivered him at Tours by the Arch-bi≈øhop, and at Lyons he met with the other Royal pilgrim, Philip the Second ≈øirnamed Augu≈øtus, King of France, but parting again by con≈øent they went ≈øeveral ways toward Syria.

King Richard, in his pa≈ø≈øage through Italy, went within fifteen Miles of Rome, and yet never vouch≈øaf'd his Holine≈øs a Vi≈øit, but told Octavian Bi≈øhop of O≈øtia, the Popes Confe≈ø≈øor that, having better objects before him, he would not ≈øtir one ≈øtep out of his way to ≈øee the Pope, becau≈øe he had lately extorted, without all rea≈øon, a great Sum of Money from the Engli≈øh Prelates: And therefore pa≈ø≈øing forward, at Me≈ø≈øina in Sicily the two Kings meet again; where likewi≈øe King Richard, to his exceeding joy, found his fleet ≈øafely arrived, but having met with much difficulty and danger in their pa≈ø≈øage. Richard learnt by his own experience, what mi≈øeries and dangers Merchants and Mariners at Sea meet withal, being always within a few inches, and after within an hairs breadth of death, which made him revoke the Law of Wracks, which intitled. the King of England to all Ship wrackt goods

Tankred was at this time King of Sicily, who, being a Ba≈øtard born, had u≈øurped the Crown, detained the Dowrie, and impri≈øoned the per≈øon of Joan, Wife to William the Late King of Sicily, and Si≈øter to K. Richard: So that he was in a mi≈øerable plight at the arrival of tho≈øe two mighty Monarchs, and knew not what cour≈øe to ≈øteer. To keep them out was impo≈ø≈øible, and above his Power, and to let them in was dangerous, and might prove his ruin, and therefore re≈øolved (how Ju≈øtly or Prudently let the Reader judge) to ≈øecure him≈øelf by creating a mi≈øunder≈øtanding between tho≈øe two Kings: And therefore applying him≈øelf to the French King, he in≈øinuated ≈øeveral fal≈øe Stories of the King of England, permitting his Subjects likewi≈øe to do the Engli≈øh all the ≈øecret mi≈øchief they could; for which Richard, who was not ignorant of what pa≈ø≈øed between him and the French King, demanded ≈øatisfaction, which was denied him, wherefore, re≈øolving to avenge him≈øelf, he a≈ø≈øaulted & took Me≈ø≈øina it ≈øelf, together with mo≈øt of the chief Forts in the I≈øland, demanding ≈øatisfaction for all the wrongs done both to him≈øelf and Si≈øter. Whereupon Tankred, though he was dull at fir≈øt, yet now being prickd with the Sword, he freely bled many Thou≈øand Ounces of
Gold, and finding that as the ca≈øe ≈øtood hi ‚Ä¢ be≈øt Thrift was to be Prodigal, he gave ou ‚Ä¢ King what conditions ≈øoever he demanded.

However the mi≈øunder≈øtanding, which he had procured between the two Royal Pilgrims, daily increa≈øed, and Richard ≈ølighting the French Kings Si≈øter, whom he had formerly promi≈øed to marry, expre≈ø≈øed more affection to Berengari ‚Ä¢
Daughter to the King of Navarr, which vexed Philip to the Heart, but ≈øome Princes interpo≈øing between them, healed the breach for the pre≈øent; but the cau≈øe remaining, the Malady quickly returned with wor≈øe ≈øymptoms then before.

King Philip, thinking to be revenged on Richard by fore, ≈øtaling the Market of Honour, and ingro≈ø≈øing all to him≈øelf, po≈øted many to Ptolemais, whil≈øt Richard followed after at his lei≈øure, taking Cyprus in his way, where reigned I≈øaac, Or, as others call him, Cur≈øac, who, under Andronicus the Grecian Emperour (when it was common for every Factious Nobleman to ≈ønatch a plank of that ≈øhipwrack'd and ≈øinking Empire) had ≈øeized on that I≈øland, and there Tyranniz'd as an ab≈øolute King, but being ≈øo fool-hardy, as to abu≈øe our Royal Pilgrim, at his Arrival there, by killing divers of his Souldiers, who landed in his I≈øland, and refu≈øing to
‚Ä¢ ermit the Sea-≈øick Lady Berengaria to ‚Ä¢ ome on Shore, he lo≈øt both him≈øelf, and ‚Ä¢ is new erected Kingdom at once. For ‚Ä¢ ing Richard ea≈øily conquered the whole ‚Ä¢ land, and honoured the in≈øolent Grecian, with the Magnificent Captivity of Silver Fetters: Yet like a noble and generous Conquerour, he ≈øet his Daughter at Liberty, and gave her Princely U≈øage; the I≈øland ‚Ä¢ he pawned to the Templars for ready Money, and becau≈øe Cyprus had been anciently accounted the Seat of Venus; that it might prove ≈øo to him, in the plea≈øant Month of May he there ≈øolemnized his Marriage with his Beloved Lady Berengaria.

Whil≈øt Richard was thus detained in Cyprus, the Siege of Ptolemais was carried on with abundance of fiercene≈øs and re≈øolution by the French King, who hoped to get the Renown of its Conque≈øt before King Richards Arrival, but found it ≈øo ≈øtrenuou≈øly defended by the Turks within, that all his ≈øtrength was not ≈øufficient to force tho≈øe Walls, which had now above 2 years with≈øtood the Chri≈øtians Batteries; & by rea≈øon of the length of the Siege the Turks and Chri≈øtians were become well acquainted with each others Way of fighting: ≈øo that what advantages happened to either ≈øide were meerly ca≈øual, and not the

In the mean while the Plague and Famine raged in the Chri≈øtian Camp, and in the compa≈øs of one year, had ≈øwept away above Fifty Princes and Prelates of note, who together with all the re≈øt of the common Souldiers, in the opinion of tho≈øe who wrote the Hi≈øtory of that Siege, went undoubtedly to Heaven; Although it were before Pope Clement the ≈øixth, had commanded the Angels, (who dur≈øt not di≈øobey him,) to convey every Soul into Paradice, which ≈øhould die in their Pilgrimage.

Among tho≈øe who ≈øurvived, no Prince ≈øhewed more Valour, and de≈øerved greater commendation than Leopoldus, Arch-Duke of Au≈øtria, who fought ≈øo long in a≈ø≈øaulting this City, that his Armour was all gore Blood, ≈øave only that part of it, which was covered with his Belt: For which rea≈øon renouncing the ≈øix Golden Larks, the Ancient Arms of his Family, he had a≈ø≈øigned him by the Emperour,
as a Te≈øtimony of his valour, a Fe≈øs Argentin a Field Gules.

And King Richard, being now at la≈øt arrived in the Camp before Ptolemais (having taken a Dromand or Saracen Ship, which he mett in his way thither, wherein were Fifteen Hundred Soldiers and two hundred and fifty Scorpions de≈øigned for the poy≈øoning of Chri≈øtians) the Siege was carried on by him, and his Engli≈øh Souldiers, more fiercely than ever it had been before. So that the Turks, de≈øpairing of relief and their provi≈øions wholly ≈øpent, offered to yield up the City, which the Chri≈øtians would not accept of, unle≈øs Saladine would promi≈øe to deliver all the Chri≈øtian Pri≈øoners which were then in his cu≈øtody, and re≈øtore them the Cro≈øs again, which he promi≈øing to do, the City was delivered and the Turki≈øh Soldiers guarded ≈øafely out of it.

The Hou≈øes, which were yet left ≈øtanding in the City, together with the Spoil and Pri≈øoners were, by the Kings of England and France, divided among them≈øelves, whereupon divers great Per≈øons, who had been ≈øharers in the pains, but were hereby excluded from the gains, departed in di≈øcontent, and King Richards Soldiers rudely pulled down the Arch-Duke
of Au≈øtria's En≈øigns, which he ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ advanced in a principal Tower in tha ‚Ä¢ City, and as ≈øome write, threw them in to the Jakes; whereat the Duke wa ‚Ä¢ highly di≈øplea≈øed, but yet wi≈øely di≈ø≈øen ‚Ä¢
bled his anger, and ≈øeemed to forget th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Injury, till he might remember it to hisadvantage: which he afterwards did, & made King Richard pay ≈øeverely for this affron ‚Ä¢ .

When the City was taken, it grieve ‚Ä¢ the Chri≈øtians, that they could not fin ‚Ä¢ out their Faithful Intelligencer, wh ‚Ä¢ had all along by his Letters acquainted them with the State of the City, b ‚Ä¢ more that the Cro≈øs did no where appear being either carele≈øly lo≈øt, or enviou ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ concealed by the Turks. They demanded „Äà‚óä„Äâ of Saladine, with the delivery of the Chri≈øtian Pri≈øoners; which he refu≈øed not but demanded a longer time for the performance, in regard the Cro≈øs could not be found. But King Richard ≈øuppo≈øing that it was only a pretence to gain time re≈øolved to have all things performed according to their agreement, which being not done, he in the heat of his Pa≈ø≈øio ‚Ä¢ commanded Seven Thou≈øand Turki≈øh Pri≈øoners, to be immediately cut to pieces for which ra≈øh and cruel act, he ≈øuffere ‚Ä¢ much in his reputation, and was looke ‚Ä¢ upon as the Murtherer of the like number
of Chri≈øtians, whom Saladine in revenge, put to the Sword: whereas on the contrary, the moderation of the French King was very much commended for ≈øparing his Pri≈øoners, and re≈øerving them to ran≈øom ≈øo many Chri≈øtians.

But that which mo≈øt ob≈øcured the Glory of this Victory was the Chri≈øtians being tent a≈øunder with Faction, and divided among them≈øelves. King Philip, the Dukes of Burgundy and Au≈øtria, mo≈øt of the Dutch and all the Genoans and Templars, fiding with King Conrade, and King Richard, Henry Count of Champaigne, with the Ho≈øpitallers, the Venetians, and Pi≈øans, taking part with Guy. Conrades ≈øide was very much weakned, by the ≈øudden departure of the French King, who eighteen days, after the taking of Ptolemais, returned home, pretending want of nece≈ø≈øaries, & indi≈øpo≈øition of body through the di≈øtemper of the Climate: but the true cau≈øe was his not induring to hear King Richards Fame ≈øo much tran≈øcend his own, together with a de≈øire to ≈øeize on the Dominions of the Earl of Flanders, who was then lately dead.

His own Souldiers mightily di≈ø≈øwaded him from returning, and be≈øought him not to ≈øtop in ≈øo glorious a work, wherein he had pro≈øpered ≈øo well already, telling

And at his departure he left his in≈øtructions, together with his Army, to the Duke of Burgundy, ordering him to move as ≈ølowly as po≈ø≈øible, in advancing that work, wherein the King of England would have all the Honour, which rendred this great undertaking le≈øs advantagious to the Chri≈øtians in Syria, than otherwi≈øe it might have been.

argument.p: Conrade ≈ølain, Guy exchanges his Kingdom for the I≈øle of Cyprus, Henry of Champaign cho≈øen King. King Richard obtains many Victories, but at la≈øt makes a di≈øhonourable Peace, and in his return home, is taken Pri≈øoner in Au≈øtria.

div.p:
SOon after the French Kings departure, Conrade King of Jeru≈øalem was cruelly murthered in the Marketplace of Tyre; the cau≈øe of who≈øe Death
is variou≈øly reported, ≈øome fal≈øely charging our King Richard with having procured it, and others ≈øay, he was killed by Humphred Prince of Thoron, for marrying I≈øabella, who had been before e≈øpou≈øed to him: But mo≈øt affirm, that he was ≈øtabbed by two A≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øines by command of their Ma≈øter the Old man of the Mountains, who≈øe only Quarrel with him was, his being a Chri≈øtian; and that the two Murtherers being immediately taken and put to a cruel Death, Gloried in the Meritoriou≈øne≈øs of their ≈øuffering. He had Reigned about five years, and left ont Daughter, Maria Jole, on whom the Templers be≈øtowed Princely Education.

But tho' Conrade was Dead, his Faction ≈øtill ≈øurvived, and tho≈øe of his party affronted King Guy, and ≈øtrove to have him depo≈øed; telling him, that the Crown was only tyed on his Head with a Womans Fillet, which being now broken, by the Death of Queen Sibyl who dyed together with all her Children, of the Plague at the Siege of Ptolomais, he had no longer any Right to the Kingdom, e≈øpecially, being a worthle≈øs and an unfortunate man: Tho' the truth is, the mea≈øuring a Princes worth by his Succe≈øs, is a Rule often fal≈øe, and always uncertain; and the common Con≈øent of all
Nations will plead this in his Favour, that having been once a King, he ought ever to remain ≈øo. But to put a ≈øinal end to this unhappy Controver≈øie, King Richard made a plea≈øing Motion, which relli≈øhed well to the Palate of that hungry Prince, offering him the I≈øland of Cyprus, in exchange for his Kingdom of Jeru≈øalem. Which motion was willingly imbraced, and the exchange actually made, to the Content of both parties, and the Kings of England bore the Title of King of Jeru≈øalem in their ≈øtyle, for many years after. But in this exchange, Guy had really the better Bargain, in regard he bought a real Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion for an Airy Title: However, he lived not long to injoy it, for he dyed ≈øoon after his Arrival there, but his Family injoyed it, for ≈øome hundred years, after which it fell by ≈øome Tran≈øaction, to the ≈øtate of Venice; and was at la≈øt wre≈øted from them by the Turks, who injoy it at this day.

Conrade being killed, and Guy having renounced his Kingdom. Henry Earl of Champaign was advanced to the Kingdom of Jeru≈øalem, by the procurement of King Richard his Uncle, who to corroborate his Election, by ≈øome Right of Succe≈ø≈øion, married I≈øabella the Widow of Conrade, and Daughter of Almerick King of Jeru≈øalem,
he was a Prince valiant enough, but in regard his Reign was ≈øhort, and mo≈øt of it ≈øpent in a Truce; he had not an opportunity to expre≈øs it: He took more delight in the ≈øtyle of Prince of Tyre, then he did in that, of being King of Jeru≈øalem, as accounting it more honourable, to be Prince of what he had, then to be called King of what he injoyed not.

And now the Chri≈øtians promi≈øing them≈øelves abundance of Peace and Tranquility, began every where to build, and to beautifie their Habitations. The Templers fortified Gaza, and King Richard repaired and walled Ptolemais, Pomphyria, Joppa, and Askelon. But ala≈øs, this ≈øhort liv'd Pro≈øperity like an Autumn Spring, came too late, and was gone too ≈øoon, to bring forth any mature Fruit: However it was now agreed on by all parties, that they ≈øhould march immediately towards the City of Jeru≈øalem, which Holy and Sacred place, was the mark at which they all principally Aimed. And having prepared all things for the putting this re≈øolution into Practice: King Richard lead the Vant Guard of Engli≈øh, the Duke of Burgundy Commanded in the main Body over his French, and James of Avergn with his Flemings, and Brabanters brought up the Rear. Saladine who under≈øtood by
his Spies, the manner of their march, Serpent like bit them by the Heels, for not far from Bethlehem, he violently a≈ø≈øaulted the Rear of their Army; but the Engli≈øh and French ≈øuddenly Wheeling about, charged the Turks mo≈øt furiou≈øly, and Emulation formerly, Poy≈øon, here proved a Cordial; every Chri≈øtian unanimou≈øly ≈øtriving, not only to Conquer their Enemies; but to overcome their Friends to, in the Honour of the Victory. And our Royal Pilgrim in this Battel was ≈øo adventrous, and fought with ≈øuch invincible Courage, and Re≈øolution again≈øt tho≈øe Enemies of Chri≈øtianity, that his Valour brought his Judgment into que≈øtion, in regard he was more carele≈øs of him≈øelf, and expo≈øed his Per≈øon to greater danger, then be≈øeemed the prudence of a General; for having received a Wound, as tho' by lo≈øing his Blood, he had received a new Addition to his Strength, he laid about him like a Mad-man, killing divers of the Infidels with his own hands. The Turks with≈øtood the Chri≈øtians force for a long time, and ≈øtrove hard to carry away the Honour of the Day; but were at la≈øt forced to give Ground, and leave the Chri≈øtians in the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Victory, which they obtained with little or no lo≈øs to them≈øelves, ≈øave James of Avergn,
who dyed here in the Bed of Honour. But there were more Turks ≈ølain in this Battel, then there had been in any other for forty years before.

And had the Chri≈øtian improved this Victory, and marched immediately to Jeru≈øalem, they might in all Probability have ≈øurprized it, whil≈øt the Turks were Blind-folded, and in a kind of a maze at this Prodigious overthrow: But the opportunity was wholly lo≈øt by the backwardne≈øs of King Richard and his Engli≈øh Soldiers, ≈øay the French Writers, whil≈øt others impute it, altogether to the Envy, and Emulation of the French, who rather cho≈øe to have ≈øo Glorious an Action left undone, then to ≈øee it performed by the Engli≈øh, together with the Treachery of Odo Duke of Burgundy, who being more grieved for the lo≈øs of his Credit, than careful to pre≈øerve a good Con≈øcience, was choaked with the ≈øhame of the ≈øin which he had ≈øwallowed, and dyed for Grief, that his holding Corre≈øpondence with the Turks, came to be di≈øcovered: But mo≈øt are of the Opinion, that Richard attempted not the taking of Jeru≈øalem, becau≈øe like a wi≈øe Architect, he intended to build his Victories, ≈øo as they might ≈øtand un≈øhaken, by ≈øecuring the Country all along as he
went. It being Sen≈øle≈øs and Imprudent to be≈øiege Jeru≈øalem an In-land City, whil≈øt the Turks were ≈øtill in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of all the Sea-Ports, and other places of Strength thereabouts.

Sometime after this Victory, he intercepted divers Camels laden with very rich Commodities; tho≈øe Ea≈øtern Wars containing a great deal of Trea≈øure in a little Room. And yet of all this, and of all that abundance of Wealth of England, Sicily and Cyprus, which he brought hither, he carried nothing home, ≈øave only one Gold-Ring, all the re≈øt being melted away, and con≈øumed in this hot Service.

He ≈øpent the Winter at Askelon, and intended the following Spring to have gone to Jeru≈øalem, had not bad News out of Europe altered his re≈øolution, and put him in mind of returning home. William Bi≈øhop of Ely, whom he had left his Vice-Roy in England, u≈øed many un≈øufferable In≈øolencies towards his Subjects: So hard and difficult a thing it is, for one of a mean and Contemptible Birth, to per≈øonate a King without going beyond his Limits, and over Acting his part. And that which was yet wor≈øe, his Brother John Earl of Morton, had con≈øpired with the French King to invade
his Dominions. Which reports, and the concluding of this War, (a Subject not likely to an≈øwer the expence and Charge of of it; e≈øpecially, now the Venetians, Genoans, Pi≈øans and Florentines were gone away with their Fleet; wi≈øely ≈øhrinking them≈øelves out of the Collar, when they found their Necks too much Galled with their hard imployment;) made him de≈øire a Peace of Saladine, who thereby finding, that he had all the Cords in his own hands, knew well enough how to play his Game, and make his be≈øt of tho≈øe Exigencies wherein he knew King Richard to be plunged; for he had tho≈øe about him, who had cunning and skill enough, to read in King Richards Face what grieved and perplexed his mind, and knew by his Spies every thing, that was worth Ob≈øervation in the Engli≈øh Army. He offered therefore to Con≈øent, that a Truce ≈øhould be concluded on for three (≈øome ≈øay five) years, upon condition that the Chri≈øtians would demoli≈øh all places which they had fortified ≈øince the taking of Ptolemais, which was in Effect to be at the Charge of undoing all that they had hitherto done. But however ≈øuch was the urgency of King Richards occa≈øion, that he was glad to accept of tho≈øe hard Conditions, tho' he hated them at his Heart.

And thus this great undertaking of tho≈øe two mighty and Warlike Kings, began with great Confidence, managed with much Courage, and attended with good Succe≈øs, ended, notwith≈øtanding with ≈øome Honour indeed to the undertakers, but no manner of Profit, either to them≈øelves, or the Chri≈øtian cau≈øe.

King Richard in this Voyage eternized his Memory, and to the Glory of the Engli≈øh Nation, render'd his Name ≈øo terrible to the Turks, that they were u≈øed to ≈øay to their Hor≈øes when they ≈øtarted for fear, what do≈øt thou think King Richard is here? But Profit, neither he, nor the French King got any, both of them loo≈øing the Hair of their Head in an acute di≈øea≈øe, which ≈øaith, one Hi≈øtorian was more then either of them got by the Voyage. And as for the poor Chri≈øtians in Syria, they left them in a far wor≈øe Ca≈øe than they found them.

But to refre≈øh the Readers Spirits a little, amid≈øt ≈øo many Mi≈øeries and ≈øad Stories, I mu≈øt not omit one thing that King Richard did in Pale≈øtine, which was no doubt, an abundant Compen≈øation for all the co≈øt and pains of his Journey: Which was his redeeming from the Turks for a great ≈øum of Money, a large Che≈øt as much as four Men could lift, full of
Holy Relicks, which precious Trea≈øure they had gotten from the Chri≈øtians, at the taking of Jeru≈øalem.

div.p:
King Richard having now ≈øigned the Peace with Saladine, and thereby ended his Pilgrimage, took Shipping in Syria to return to his Kingdom; but meeting with a Storm on the Coa≈øt of Germany,

Meladine King of Egypt, ≈øeeing the deplorable Mi≈øery of tho≈øe drowned Chri≈øtians, and the Con≈øtancy, and Patience wherewith they indured their Calamity, was moved with Compa≈ø≈øion towards them; being him≈øelf as was thought, ≈øomewhat inclined to ibrace the Chri≈øtian Religion, and offered them their Lives upon condition, that they would quit the Country and re≈øtore Damiata. City, to prepare them for the Surrendering of it, but they within the City being them≈øelves ≈øafe on the ≈øhore, knew not how to ≈øimpathi≈øe with their Poor Brethren in Shipwrack, and therefore told the Me≈ø≈øengers that tho≈øe drowned Pilgrims de≈øerved no pity, in regard they had invited this mi≈øery upon them≈øelves by their own ra≈øhne≈øs, and that if they yielded up this City for nothing, which co≈øt ≈øo many Lives, they ≈øhould thereby expo≈øe them≈øelves to the deri≈øion of the whole World; that if tho≈øe Pilgrims peri≈øhed, more might be had, but no more Damata's, it being a place of ≈øuch Importance that it would always be a curb to the excur≈øions of the Egyptian King, but however tho≈øe poor di≈øtre≈ø≈øed wretches had ≈øome friends in the City, who confe≈ø≈øed that the Voyage was indeed undertaken unadvi≈øedly, and was ju≈øtly to be blamed, but yet pleaded that wor≈øe and more incon≈øiderate projects had ≈øome times been undertaken by others, and when they have been Crowned with Succe≈øs, have pa≈ø≈øed unque≈øtioned, and ≈øo they ≈øuppo≈øed would this have done, had it Succeeded, and that therefore it was mo≈øt unrea≈øonable to add mi≈øery to the mi≈øerable, be≈øeeching them to pity their Brethren, and not leave them in that forlorn ≈øtate.

But finding their arguments to avail little, they betook them≈øelves to their Arms, re≈øolving to force the adver≈øe party to re≈øign the City, and King John who of all others had the lea≈øt rea≈øon to pity them, in regard their project was wholly again≈øt his advice, was notwith≈øtanding ≈øo touched with a ≈øence of their calamity, that he generou≈øly threatned in ca≈øe they refu≈øed to ≈øurrender it, to give Meladine, Ptolemais in Syria, in the ≈øtead of it, whereupon they con≈øented, and Damiata was re≈øtored to the Turks, and the Legate and his Army let out of the trap wherein they were taken, Meladine out of his Princely goodne≈øs furni≈øhing them with Victuals, and Hor≈øes to carry their feeble per≈øons upon, and thus the Chri≈øtians received an overthrow without a wound, and the Turks obtained an ab≈øolute Victory without Blood.

And there being at this time, be≈øides the agreement for the Exchange of Damiata, a Peace made with the Turks for eight years, whereby things were ≈øetled in Syria, King John took a Journey to Rome, where he was Honourably entertained by the Pope; And ≈øhortly after tho' for what rea≈øon I cannot find, he re≈øigned the Kingdom of Jeru≈øalem to Froderick, the ≈øecond Emperour of Germany, upon
condition that he ≈øhould marry Jole the only Daughter of King John, by his fir≈øt Wife, altho' by a ≈øecond Wife he had another named Martha, Marryed to Robert Emperour of Greece, ≈øo that by Marriage he was now become Father to both the Emperours of the East and West.

div.p:
Some condemn his re≈øignation as an unadvi≈øed Act, and conclude that if he had not fir≈øt parted with his wits he would never have parted ≈øo freely with his Kingdom. But others on the contrary commend it, as a Wi≈øe and Con≈øiderate Action, and give us tho≈øe rea≈øons to prove it. Fir≈øt, his Wife was dead, by who≈øe Right he held his Kingdom. Secondly he knew the Turks power to Invade it, and his own weakne≈øs to defend it. Thirdly, before his re≈øignation, he had little left but the bare Title, and after it he had nothing le≈øs; it being ≈øo cu≈øtomary for all men to ≈øalute him by the name of King of Jeru≈øalem, that he was called ≈øo to his dying day. Fourthly he thereby provided better for his Daughter, then otherwi≈øe he could in all probability have done. And La≈øtly becau≈øe he got more after the ≈øurrender, then he did before, for in England he received many great pre≈øents from Henry the Third; In France, be≈øides rich gifts left to him≈øelf he had the managing of 60000 Crowns, left by Phillip Augu≈øtus the French King, to the Templars, for the carrying on the Holy War. In Spain he got a rich Wife, Beringaria the Daughter of the King of Castile, and in Italy he ta≈øted largely of the Popes liberality, lived there in great
plenty, but at la≈øt Perfidiou≈øly rai≈øing Rebellion again≈øt the Emperour of Germany, his Son in Law, at the In≈øtigation of the Pope, he lo≈øt the General E≈øteem of mo≈øt men, and went off the ≈øtage without Applau≈øe.

Fredericks Nuptials with the Lady Jole, was ≈øolemnized at Rome in the pre≈øence of the Pope, with all the Ceremonies of Maje≈øty imaginable, and he ingaged him≈øelf by promi≈øe, that he would within two years pro≈øecute his Title in Pale≈øtine, but by Di≈øcords and Jealou≈øies between the Pope and him; he was much longer before he got things in readine≈øs to march, and when he was on his way to Pale≈øtine, the Plague ≈øeized on his Army at Brindi≈øi in Italy, where he likewi≈øe was ≈øhortly after Vi≈øited with a de≈øperate fit of ≈øickne≈øs which ≈øtayed his Journey for many Months.

It went again≈øt the grain with the Pope to have the Emperor ≈øo near him, and therefore he Excommunicated him afre≈øh, (having done it divers times before,) pretending his ≈øickne≈øs was only the Cramp of Lazine≈øs, and charging him with the unju≈øt ≈øeizing on the goods of Lewis Lantgrave of Thuringia, who died a little before in the Camp, The Emperour prote≈øted his innocency and accu≈øed
the Pope of inju≈øtice, offering for the proof of it to put him≈øelf on the tryal of all Chri≈øtian Princes. However at la≈øt health came, and Frederick departed with his Fleet for the Holy Land, wherea ‚Ä¢ the Pope who was neither well full nor fa≈øting ≈øtormed exceedingly, and be libel'd him more then ever, becau≈øe he had for≈øooth departed without his Fathers Ble≈ø≈øing, or being Ab≈øolved and Reconciled to his Mother the Church.

But we may ob≈øerve that Gods Ble≈ø≈øing often times goes along with the Popes cur≈øes, for the Fame of Fredericks Valour and his Virgin Fortune, never yet ≈øtained with ill Succe≈øs, ha≈øtning like an Harbinger before perpared Victory to entertain him at his arrval there, This Emperor Swifter then Cae≈øar him≈øelf, overcame before he came to Pale≈øtine; ≈øo that Coradine being dead and his Children in their Minority, the Sultan of Babylon who was then of greate≈øt Authority among the Turks, and Governed Syria, offered him what he could never have expected, viz. To re≈øtore him Jeru≈øalem, and all Pale≈øtine in as full and ample a manner as it was enjoyed by Baldwine the Fourth, before it was Conquered by S ‚Ä¢ ladine, and to relea≈øe all Chri≈øtian Pri≈øoners upon condition that the Turks might be permitted in ≈ømall numbers
to have acce≈øs to the Sepulcher, they likewi≈øe having ≈øome Knowledg off, and ≈øome kind of Veneration for Chri≈øt.

Before Frederick would ratifie any thing by Oath he ≈øent to have the Popes approbation, but hearing that he had Impri≈øoned his Me≈ø≈øengers and in a mo≈øt contemptuous manner torn his Letters, he concluded a Truce with the Sultan for Ten years without the Popes con≈øent, and entering on Ea≈øter-day Triumphantly into Jeru≈øalem, he Crowned him≈øelf King with his own hands, for the Patriarch, the Ma≈øter of the Templars, and all the Clergy ab≈øented them≈øelves, neither was there any Ma≈øs Sung in the City, ≈øo long as the Emperor ≈øtaid there, becau≈øe he was Excommunicated.

And thus by the Valour and Policy of Frederick, was the Holy Land recovered without blood, which had been for many years before attempted without ≈øucce≈øs, and the affairs of Palestine brought into a good condition, & rendered capable of improving, had not the Pope ruined all by forcing the Emperor to return ≈øooner then he intended to ≈øupre≈øs the Rebellion, which the Pope had cau≈øed John Bren to rai≈øe again≈øt him at home, At his departure he appointed Reinoldus Duke of Bavaria to be his Lieutenant in Syria, who wi≈øely
di≈øcharged his Office, and pre≈øerved the Peace intire, which was concluded with the Sultan of Babylon, although the Temp
‚Ä¢ ars endeavoured to bring that Ten years Truce to an untimely end, it being an in≈øufferable thing with them to fa≈øt from Fighting, which was Meat and Drink to their Turbulent Spirits, Condemning him for his want of Zeal in the Holy War, and giving him many a lift to heave him from his place, but ≈øtill he ≈øate ≈øure nor was he much troubled at the envy of Henry King of Cyprus who challenged the principality of Antioch, as next of kin the la≈øt decea≈øed Prince; for the Duke met him and defeated him in battle, and gave that Principality to Frederick, ba≈øe Son to the Emperor.

But that which kept both Turks and Chri≈øtians in awe, and made them the more carefull to ob≈øerve the Truce, was their mutual fear of the Tartars, a fierce People which at this time took their fir≈øt flight out of their own ne≈øt into the Neighbouring Countries, they were anciently called Scythians, and Inhabited the Northern parts of A≈øia a country never Conquered by any of the Monarchs, being priviledged from their Victorious Arms by its own barrenne≈øs, which was the rea≈øon why after they had made ≈øeveral incur≈øions into Europe,
and the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, they found it ≈øo ≈øweet that they cared not to return home.

They were by their multitudes and fercene≈øs become ≈øo formidable that the Pope him≈øelf began to fear them in Italy, to prevent which he ≈øent Askelin a Frier much famed in tho≈øe days, and three others to Convert them to the Christian Religion, who in≈øtead of in≈øtructing them the Rudiments of Chri≈øtianity, acquainted them with the greatne≈øs and power of the Pope, who was as he told them, exalted above all the Princes of Europe, but Baiothnoi Chief Captain of the Tartarian Army (for they were not admitted to the Great Cham him≈øelf) crying quits with this Frier, outvyed him in di≈øcribing his Cham, who≈øe greatne≈øs and Divinity he affirmed to exceed that of the Popes, and ≈øent him back with a blunt Letter, which he concluded thus, If thou wilt ≈øet upon our Land and Inheritance, it behoveth that Thou Pope in thy proper Per≈øon come unto us, and that Thou come to him who containeth the Face of the Whole Earth, meaning their Great Cham.

Never did his Holine≈øs ≈øo meet with his match before, however he loved his Flock in Europe too well to run the hazard of lo≈øing them by a long Journey into Tartaria, and ≈øo the Conver≈øion of the Tartarians was neglected.

About this time likewi≈øe the Grecian Emperour, who had been now near ≈øixty years confined to the Citys of Nice and Adrianople, only recovered every foot of Land that the Latins had won from the Greeks, after it had been enjoyed by five Succe≈øive Latine Emperours, except what was enjoyed by the Venetians, who kept Candia, till lately wre≈øted from them by the Turks, & pre≈øently after the Greek Church wholly ca≈øt of their ≈øubjection to the Pope, and declared the Patriarch of Con≈øtantinople to be ab≈øolute of him≈øelf, without having any dependency on Rome, the occa≈øion of their di≈øavowing the Popes Authority was this Germanus, being upon this new revolution of the Grecian Empire, cho≈øen Patriarch of Constantinople, a certain Archbi≈øhop preferred by him, went to Rome, there to have his confirmation, but finding that Court ≈øo unrea≈øonable in their demands of Fees, that it would weaken him to be confirmed, and ≈øhake his E≈øtate to ≈øettle him in his Bi≈øhoprick, he returned again without confirmation, but with ≈øo great an outcry upon the Extortion of Rome, that the Patriarch and the whole Clergy for ever after threw off the Popes heavy Yoke, which they were no longer able to bear.

His Holine≈øs ≈øtormed exceedingly at this
lo≈øs, and therefore di≈øpairing to reduce them by fair means, proclaimed open War again≈øt them, and re≈øolved to ≈øend an Army of Cro≈ø≈øed Soldiers again≈øt tho≈øe Schi≈ømatical Grecians, as he had formerly done again≈øt the Albigen≈øes: It being cu≈øtomary with that imperious Prelate, to make u≈øe of the Secular Power, as his Hang-man, to execute tho≈øe whom he ≈øhall plea≈øe to condemn. But his Commands were herein but little regarded, very few Volunteers entering them≈øelves for this Service, and mo≈øt men entertaining a Religious Horror and Dete≈øtation of ≈øo odious an Imployment.

This irrepairable rent and divi≈øion between the two Churches was very advantagious to the Turks, and a greath inderance to the Holy War; for the Greeks in Syria, who had hitherto lived in ≈øome kind of friendly corre≈øpondency with the Latins, differing indeed in Judgment, but complying in Affections, and uniting again≈øt the Turk, the common Enemy of both, began now to conceive ≈øo great a hatered for the Latins, that they wi≈øhed the Turk, from whom they expected fair Quarter, the free Exerci≈øe of their Religion, and a ≈øecure dwelling in any City, for paying a ≈øet Tribute, might conquer rather than their fellow Chri≈øtians, from whom
they expected nothing but a forcing of their Con≈øcience, and the bringing their Souls into ≈øubjection to the Popes Supremacy; and therefore from thence forward, never lent a helping hand to that War.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: The Voyage of Theobald, Kingof Navarre; Of Robert Earl of Cornwall. Jeru≈øalem taken by the Cora≈øines.

div.p:
THe Ten Years Truce made by Frederick, being ended, he ordered Reinold, his Vice-Roy, to conclude another, for the ≈øame term of years; which, tho' honourable enough, and without any other fault, than Frederick's having made it, yet the Templars would not indure it, pretending, that it was a great Indignity to the Chri≈øtians, for the Turks to have acce≈øs to the Sepulchre. And Pope Gregory, to de≈øpite the Emperour, commanded his Trumpeters, the Dominican and Franci≈øcan Fryers, to ≈øound a fre≈øh Alarum to the Holy War; who amplifying, with their Rhetorick, the Calamity of the Chri≈øtians,
the Tyranny of the Turks, the Merit of the Cau≈øe, and the Probability of Succe≈øs, prevailed with many to undertake the Voyage; the principal whereof was, Theobald, King of Navarre; Almerick, Earl of Montfort; Henry, Earl of Champaigne; Peter, Earl of Bretaigne; who having no Ships, were forced to march with their Armies by Land, through Grecia, where they were entertained, as others had been before them, with Treachery, Famine, and all the Mi≈øeries that could attend an unfortunate Army; in≈øomuch, that none ever after adventured to go that way into the Holy Land.

But having pa≈ø≈øed the Bo≈øporus, they marched to Antioch, being more than half of them de≈øtroyed by the Turks in their pa≈ø≈øage thither, and the re≈øt mi≈øerably weaken'd and almo≈øt dead with ≈øickne≈øs and famine. However, after they had for ≈øometime refre≈øhed them≈øelves there, the Templars conducted them to Gaza, where they fell to ≈øpoiling and foraging the Sultan's Country, a≈ø≈øaulting no place of ≈øtrength, but only poor Villages, who thought them≈øelves ≈øufficiently walled by the Truce. But as they were returning home, laden with Trea≈øure, the Turks in great numbers fell upon them near Gaza; where, after a bloody fight, wherein the
Chri≈øtians behaved them≈øelves with ≈øo much bravery, that they were rather killed than conquered, they were utterly overthrown; Earl Henry being ≈ølain, Almerick taken pri≈øoner, and the King of Navarre forced to ≈øave him≈øelf by the ≈øwiftne≈øs of his Spani≈øh Gennet.

In the mean while, the other Chri≈øtians looked on and ≈øaw their Brethren ≈ølaughtered before their faces, without being able to help them, in regard their hands were tyed by the Truce; and Reinoldus charged them not to infringe the Peace made with the Sultan. As for the King of Navarre, he ≈øtole home with as much fecre≈øie as po≈ø≈øible, being greatly a≈øhamed, that his Voyage, from which ≈øo much was expected, had effected nothing, but the ruin of its undertakers.

Fifteen days after his departure, Richard, Earl of Cornwall, and Brother to King Henry the Third, landed at Ptolemais, accompanied by Theodoricus, Lord Prior of the Engli≈øh Ho≈øpitallers, divers Barons, and an Army of brave and well-appointed Soldiers, where he was joyfully received, e≈øpecially by the Clergy, who Sang at his arrival, Ble≈ø≈øed is he who cometh in the Name of the Lord.

This Prince was our Engli≈øh Croe≈øus, and the Tinn-Mines in Cornwall were his Indies
that inriched him, ≈øo that England never had a poorer King, and a richer Subject, than tho≈øe two Brothers. When he was got as far as the Mediterranean Sea, the the Pope ≈øent his Legate, to command him back, and forbid his proceeding any farther in his Voyage. Whereat our Heroick Pilgrim was ≈øomewhat a≈øtoni≈øhed, that the Pope ≈øhould ≈øo ≈øolemnly ≈øummon, and then as ≈øuddenly di≈øcharge his Holy Souldiers, as tho' he de≈øigned only to delude peoples devotions with fal≈øe alarums. However, having vowed the Voyage, and his Honour and Trea≈øure being ingaged therein, he re≈øolved that his Holine≈øs ≈øhould not with a breath bla≈øt his generous Re≈øolutions, but went forward, notwith≈øtanding this Command to the contrary.

The Sultans in Syria, hearing of his arrival, offered him Peace; but whil≈øt he was treating of it, he fortified Askelon, which was the be≈øt Harbour in all Syria, and beautified it with Marble and Statues, cau≈øed the Chri≈øtians, killed at the late Battel of Gaza, to be decently buried, and gave a Prie≈øt an yearly Salary, to Pray for their Souls: ≈øo that the living being much taken with his kindne≈øs to the dead, he thereby purcha≈øed as much love and honour, as tho' he had ≈ølain ≈øo many
Turks. And having at la≈øt concluded a Peace with the Sultans for Ten Years; wherein it was agreed, That all Chri≈øtian Captives ≈øhould be relea≈øed, ≈øeveral Forts re≈øtored, and things reduced to the ≈øame ≈øtate they were at the fir≈øt Peace made with Frederick the Emperour. He returned home with abundance of Honour, Having, ≈øays the Hi≈øtorian, compelled tho≈øe Infidels to offer Terms of Peace, without offering them any other violence, than ≈øhewing his Sword in the Scabbard, without ever drawing it. And indeed ≈øuch was the general e≈øteem which he obtained by his Succe≈øs in this Voyage, that he afterwards bid fair for the Imperial Crown of Germany.

Not long after the Earls return, died Reinoldus, Frederick's Lieutenant in Syria, in who≈øe Grave was buried all the Happine≈øs and Glory of the Chri≈øtians in Pale≈øtine. For now the lawle≈øs Templars would ob≈øerve no other Rule than their own Will, and the inundation of the rude Tartars, having, maugre all oppo≈øition, run over all the North of A≈øia, and forced many Nations to for≈øake their ancient Habitations; among whom was a certain People, called Cora≈øine, who being thus unkennelled, had recour≈øe to the Sultan of Babylon, de≈øiring him to give them a place to live in. The Sultan, who was free
enough of that which was none of his own, frankly gave them all the Land that the Chri≈øtians held in Syria, upon condition, that they would conquer it; which he told them was ea≈øie to do, in regard the People were few and weak, and the Country rich and fruitful.

The Cora≈øines being thus animated by the by the Sultan, came with their Wives and Children and their whole Hou≈øholds into Syria, to win Hou≈øes and Land for them there. And finding the City of Jeru≈øalem unguarded, and without the lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpition of an Enemy, ea≈øily ≈øurprized it, and entered without re≈øi≈øtance. Many of the Chri≈øtians thereupon flying out of the City with their Wives and Families, took their cour≈øe towards Joppa, but unfortunately looking back, and ≈øeeing their own En≈øigns advanced on the Walls, were ≈øo infatuated as to go back to the City again, upon a confute, that their fellows had beaten the Cora≈øines, and by tho≈øe Banners, invited them to return, whereby they were every Mother's Child of them ≈ølain.

Things being brought to this pa≈øs in Syria, a de≈øperate Di≈øea≈øe mu≈øt have a de≈øperate Remedy, whereupon the Chri≈øtians clapt up a ha≈øty Peace with the two Sultans of Dama≈øcus and Cracci, between
whom, and the Sultan of Babylon, there was at that time ≈øome di≈øcord. And ≈øwearing them to be faithful, borrowed an Army of their Forces, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them in taking vengeance on the Cora≈øines. Robert, Patriarch of Jeru≈øalem, was the chief Commander, and St. Luke's day the time agreed on for this fatal Battel, which was fought on a Plain near Tyberius. But the two Armies were no ≈øooner joyned, but the Turks, who were placed in the front of the Battel, ran over to the Enemy, or at lea≈øt fled through cowardize, ≈øo that the Chri≈øtians being over-powered in number, though they made a great ≈ølaughter of their Enemies, were at la≈øt utterly overthrown, and mo≈øt of them ≈ølain, there e≈øcaping no more, but Three of the Teutonick Order, Eighteen Templers, and Nineteen Ho≈øpitallers, be≈øides the Patriarch; who ≈øays of him≈øelf, That God, accounting him unwortby of Martyrdom, permitted him to e≈øcape among the rest. The Corafines improving this Victory, won all from the Chri≈øtians, except Tyre, Ptolemais, and Antioch, with a few Forts.

So that the Chri≈øtians were beaten by a beaten People, who ≈øhortly after falling out with the Sultan of Babylon, were by him wholly routed out, ≈øo as none of their Name remained. And it is very ob≈øervable,
that all Hi≈øtorians, both before and after this time, are wholly ≈øilent concerning them; whereby it ≈øeems, as tho' God had created this People to puni≈øh the Chri≈øtian, and as ≈øoon as they had done their work, annihilated them again.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: The French King's Voyage into Pale≈øtine: He carries the War into Egypt again: Damiata taken the ≈øecond time, but afterwards exchanged for King Lewis.

div.p:
ABout two years after this overthrow, Lewis the Ninth of that Name, King of France, arrived in Pale≈øtine, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Chri≈øtians, in recovering what they had lo≈øt. That which moved him to undertake this Voyage, was his recovering of a de≈øperate fit of ≈øickne≈øs, upon the application of a Piece of the Cro≈øs. He was accompanied therein, be≈øides three of his own Brothers, and divers of the French Nobility, by William Long≈øpath, Earl of Shrewsbury, with a brave company of valiant Engli≈øh Soldiers. When he came to Cyprus, he was met by an Emba≈ø≈øadour
from a great Tartarian Prince, who in vited, by the fame of his Piety, acquainted him with his de≈øign to embrace the Chri≈øtian Religion. He received and entertained the Emba≈ø≈øadours with much affability, di≈ømi≈ø≈øed them with liberal Gifts, and by them ≈øent, as a Pre≈øent to their Ma≈øter, a curious Tent, wherein the Hi≈øtory of the Bible was very dexteriou≈øly and richly wrought in Needle-work, hoping thereby to catch his Soul in his Eyes, Pictures being in that Age of Ignorance accounted Lay-mens Books, tho' ≈øince they have been generally condemned, as full of many damnable Errata's, and never publi≈øhed by any Authority of the King of Heaven, to be either the means or workers of Faith.

Thither al≈øo the Templers, who were afraid of being checked by this Pious King for their debauched Lives, wrote to him to accept of a Peace, which the King of Egypt offered to make with the Chri≈øtians. But he being informed by the King of Syria, that it was only a trick of the Templers, to prevent his intentions of going into Syria, to behold their wickedne≈øs, commanded the Grand Ma≈øter, that from thence forward, upon the price of his Head, he ≈øhould receive no Me≈ø≈øages, nor hold any corre≈øpondence with the Enemy,
re≈øolving with him≈øelf once more to invade Egypt, and make that Country the Seat of the War.

But having once declared his intentions, and making no great ha≈øte to put it into execution, Ateladine had time enough to provide again≈øt the ≈øtorm, by fortifying the Sea-Coa≈øt, which he did for an Hundred and Eighty Miles together; ≈øo that their landing was now much more difficult than when King John invaded it. However, Lewis being re-inforced with a new Army, by Robert, Duke of Burgundy, and Alphon≈øe, the King's Brother, ≈øet forward for Egypt, and intended to land near Damiata: But the Governour with a Band of re≈øolute Mammalakes, oppo≈øed it, between whom, and the Christians, there was for ≈øome hours a fierce and bloody Fight, wherein the Turks were at la≈øt overthrown and forced to fly into the Town, leaving the Christians Landing-place, without any other Guard, but their Governour and Five Hundred of their be≈øt Soldiers, whom they left dead on the place.
