div.p: Damiata was a City ≈øo ≈øtrong and well fortified, that the taking of it was accounted a good Task, if performed by an Army within the compa≈øs of a Year. But tho≈øe within remembring the Mi≈øeries of the la≈øt Siege, and fearing the ≈øame Tragedy would be acted over again, ≈øet fire to the Hou≈øes, and in the Night ≈øaved them≈øelves by flight; whereupon the French i≈ø≈øued in, and quenching the fire, ≈øaved abundance of Trea≈øure from the fury of the flames. Which Lo≈øs ≈øo di≈øcouraged Meladine, that to purcha≈øe Peace with the Christians, he offered to re≈øtore them the whole Kingdom of Jeru≈øalem, in as ample a manner as ever it had been enjoyed by any of their Predece≈ø≈øors, to relea≈øe all Pri≈øoners, and disbur≈øe a great Sum of Money to defray the Charge of the War. But ≈øuch was their Pride and Folly, that they refu≈øed to accept of it, unle≈øs Alexandria, the be≈øt Port in all Egypt, were given them as an Over-plus; the Pope's Legate, and Robert, Earl of Artois, per≈øuading them to grant Peace upon no other terms. Wherefore the Turk ≈øeeing them≈øelves in ≈øo de≈øperate a condition, their Extremity rendered their Sword the keener, and made them provide with the greater re≈øolution to defend their Country to the utmo≈øt.

About this time there aro≈øe a difference between the French and the Engli≈øh, to the great prejudice of their Proceedings. And Meladine, King of Egypt, died likewi≈øe the ≈øame Year, and left his imbroiled Kingdom to Melcch≈øala, his Son.

From Damiata the French marched up towards Cairo, the Governor whereof being offended with the new King, promi≈øed to deliver it into their hands. And having pa≈ø≈øed an arm of the River Nilus, Earl Robert marched forward with a third part of the Army and ≈øuddenly a≈ø≈øaulted the Turks in their Tents, whil≈øt the King was ab≈øent, and put them to flight; which Victory ≈øo lifted him up with conceit, that he adventured contrary to the advice of the Ma≈øter of the Templers, to ≈øet on the whole Turki≈øh Power, which lay incamped not far off, without ≈øtaying for the re≈øt of the Army, whereby he was utterly overthrown, and as he was cro≈ø≈øing the River, in his flight, found Water enough to drown him, tho' not to wa≈øh away the ≈øtain of ra≈øhne≈øs and cowardize from his memory; and our Engli≈øh Earl refu≈øing to fly, died fighting in the mid≈øt of his Enemies, there e≈øcaping no more but four per≈øons to carry News of this fatal overthrow to the re≈øt of the Army.

It is ea≈øier for the Reader to conceive, than for my Pen to expre≈øs, the general grief wherewith the≈øe doleful Tydings were received by the French, among whom the Plague raged ≈øo furiou≈øly, that it daily ≈øwept away Thou≈øands. And to increa≈øe their ≈øorrow, ≈øeveral ≈øick per≈øons, whom the King had ≈øent down the River to Damiata, were ≈øet upon by the Egyptian King, and having neither Hands to fight, nor Legs to run, were every one either burned or drowned, except Alexander Gifford, an Engli≈øh-man, who≈øe Name and Family ≈øtill remains at Chellingworth in Stafford-≈øhire, who acquainted the French with what had happened. They would now have been glad of tho≈øe Terms, which a little before they ≈ølighted, but it was too late, for the Turks now ≈øcorned to treat with them.

The French would have had the King provided for his own ≈øafety, by flying back to Damiata. But he refu≈øed, and re≈øolving to live or die, overcome or peri≈øh with them, marched forward to the fatal place, where the la≈øt Battel was fought. And whil≈øt they were a≈øtoni≈øhed at the ≈øight of their mangled fellows, the Egyptian King ≈øet upon them with an infinite number of men, and put them all (being but few in number, and tho≈øe very weak) to
the ≈øword, except Lewis and his two Brothers, whom he took Pri≈øoners.

The Turks having thus ≈ølain all the French Pilgrims, in≈øtantly marched up with their En≈øigns to Damiata, hoping thereby to ≈øurprize it, which if they had done, King Lewis had been for ever lo≈øt. But God di≈øappointed them, for they were ea≈øily di≈øcovered, notwith≈øtanding their di≈øgui≈øe, and forced to go away without their de≈øire.

The News of this ≈øorrowful Accident coming to Europe, filled every one with grief, and made Henry, King of England, who had made great preparation to undertake the Voyage, to alter his mind, and imploy his Money to a better u≈øe.

But to return to Egypt: Melech≈øala did not long ≈øurvive this Victory, being ≈ølain ≈øoon after by Tanquemine, a ≈øturdy Mammaluke, who ≈øucceeded him in the Egyptian Kingdom, by whom King Lewis was relea≈øed, in exchange for Damiata; being obliged, be≈øides the ≈øurrender of the City, to pay many Thou≈øand Pounds for the relea≈øing of Chri≈øtian Captives, and to make ≈øatisfaction for the Damage done in Egypt; for the ≈øecuring whereof, he was forced to pawn to the Turks, the Pyx and Host: whence it is, that a Wafer-Cake and a Box is always wrote in the Borders of that
Tape≈øtry which we have brought us out of Egypt, as a perpetual Memorial of that Victory. But tho' Lewis was ≈øet at liberty, yet he got not home, till four years after.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: The Mammalukes de≈øcribed: The Death of Frederick: The Conver≈øion of the Tartars; And the extingui≈øhing the Caliphs of Babylon: Charles made King of Sicily and Jeru≈øalem: King Lewis makes a ≈øecond Voyage.

div.p:
THo≈øe Mammalukes which had now ≈øeized on the Kingdom of Egypt were the Children of Christian-Parents, which were by Saladine and his Succe≈ø≈øors taught the Mahometan Super≈øtition, and in≈øtructed in all Military Di≈øcipline at ≈øeveral Nur≈øeries, and being found by their Valour and Courage to be the chief ≈øupport of the Turki≈øh Kings, were by them advanced to the chief places of profit and tru≈øt, and thereby the better enabled to pull down their rai≈øers. Which was performed during the captivity of King Lewis, by Tarquemine,
who ≈ølew Melech≈øala, and thinking it unfit ≈øo great a Prince ≈øhould go to the grave alone, ≈øent all his Children after him. And was afterwards cho≈øen by the re≈øt of the Mammalukes, King of Egypt; whereupon he, by their advice and con≈øent, made ≈øeveral Laws, which were ever afterward ob≈øerved by them as irrevokable, The fir≈øt whereof was,
That the Sultan, or chief of the ≈øervile Empire, ≈øhould not ≈øucceed by Inheritance, but be cho≈øen out of the Mammalukes.
The ≈øecond, That none ≈øhould be admitted into the Order of the Mammalukes, that were born either of Turki≈øh or Jewi≈øh Parents, but only ≈øuch as were born Chri≈øtians.
The third was, That tho' the Sons of Mammalukes ≈øhould injoy their Fathers Lands and Wealth, yet they ≈øhould not take upon them the Name and Honour of a Mammaluke.
The fourth was, That the Native Egyptians ≈øhould be permitted the u≈øe of no other Weapons, but ≈øuch wherewith they were to fight against Weeds and Till and Manure their Land.
There were in this Government ≈øeveral things worthy admiration.
Fir≈øt, That of Slaves they ≈øhould act the King, without playing the Tyrant.
Secondly, That they ≈øhould neglect their own Children when it is common for other men to idolize them and ≈øacrifice all that they have to their welfare.
Thirdly, That they ≈øhould not fall out in the Election of their Kings, in regard they were all equal among them≈øelves.

La≈øtly, That it ≈øhould indure ≈øo long, for it la≈øted Two hundred ≈øixty and ≈øeven Years, till overcome by Selimus, the great Turki≈øh Emperour, in the Year 1517. by the help of the Janizaries, an Order of Men for Birth and Breeding not unlike them≈øelves.

In that Year likewi≈øe, it being a Year of great Revolutions, died Frederick, Emperour of Germany and King of Jeru≈øalem, whereupon followed an Interegnum in that Kingdom for fourteen Years together; the right indeed lay in Conrade, Frederick's Son, by Jole, King John's Daughter; but he was ≈øo imployed in defending him≈øelf
in Sicily, again≈øt Maufred his Ba≈øtard Brother, (who quickly after di≈øpatched him out of the way) that he had no lei≈øure to look after the fragments of the Kingdom of Jeru≈øalem.

Near about this time a certain Hungarian Pea≈øant, ≈øaid to have been an Apo≈øtate to Mahomet, and well learned, gathered together ≈øeveral Thou≈øand people, who took on them the Name and Habit of Pa≈øtorelli, in imitation of tho≈øe in the Go≈øpel who were warned by Angels to go to Bethlehem, they had the Holy Lamb for their En≈øign, and pretended to have intelligence from Heaven to march into the Holy Land, but mi≈øtaking West for the Ea≈øt, they ≈øhaped their cour≈øe into France and committing ≈øeveral outrages that no way ≈øuited either with their Habit or Banner, they were incountred near Burdeaux, and three≈øcore Thou≈øand of them ≈ølain, and the re≈øt di≈øper≈øed.

Things being now brought into a ≈øad and deplorable condition in Syria, without any hope of amendment, behold a ≈øtrange and unexpected accident revived them again! For Haito King of Armenia taking the pains to travel him≈øelf to Margo, the Great Cham of Tartaria, to acquaint him with the danger he was in from the Turks as well as others, telling him, Tho' he lay
≈øomething out of their way, yet the only favour he mu≈øt expect from them was to be la≈øt devoured, whereupon he not only promi≈øed to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Chri≈øtians in ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing them, but him≈øelf, and by his example, a great part of the Country imbraced the Christian Faith, and thereupon ≈øent Haalon his Brother with a great Army to ≈øuppre≈øs the Turks, and a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Chri≈øtians in recovering what they had lo≈øt, in the performing whereof his Army ≈øeemed to ride po≈øt, conquering Per≈øia in as little time as one can well travel it within ≈øix Months: The City of Samarchanda was the only place that re≈øi≈øted him, and therefore being unwilling to tempt his Fortune with a long ≈øiege, he left it to one of his Captains, who be≈øieged it ≈øeven and twenty year, and at la≈øt did not take it, but had it ≈øurrendred to him.

Haalon having Conquered Per≈øia marched to Babylon, the Caliph whereof called Musteazem, Idolized his wealth ≈øo much that he would not provide nece≈ø≈øaries for the defence of the City, ≈øo that it became an ea≈øie Conque≈øt to this Tartarian Prince, who having fami≈øhed the Covetous Caliph to death filled his mouth, with melted Gold, and now Mo≈øques every where went down, and Churches went up, from thence he went into Me≈øopotamia, where having
Conquered the City of Aleppo and Ede≈ø≈øa. he re≈øtored them to the Chri≈øtians, and many other places which he wan from the Turks, whereby he ≈øo awed Melechem the Mammaluke who Succeeded Tarminus in Egypt that he dur≈øt not budg.

But of this Tartarian help they were altogether unworthy, in regard they would not be at lea≈øure to make u≈øe of it, but bu≈øied them≈øelves in private di≈ø≈øentions, the Genoans and Ventians two ≈øtates in Italy, who had thrown of the Imperial Command, and had erected them≈øelves into commonwealths, being not content to quarrel at home would needs go into Syria to fight it out there, that ≈øo the Turks might look on and laugh at them, the pretence of the quarrel was about ≈øuperiority in the Church of St. Sabbas, which was apointed by the Pope for them and the Pi≈øans, who likewi≈øe ingaged them≈øelves in the quarrel ≈øomtimes ≈øiding with one ≈øide and ≈øome times with the other.

The Venetians being at length compelled by the Genoans to for≈øake the City, were ≈øo incen≈øed thereat, that they came with thirteen Galleys, and having forced a≈øunder the chain which-cro≈ø≈øed the Haven, burned five & twenty of the Genoans Ships, that lay there; to revenge which lo≈øs the ≈øtate of Genoa ≈øent a great Navy into Syria,
which meeting with the Duke of Venice at Tyre, with the united power of the Venetians and Pi≈øans, being in all ≈øeventy four Ve≈ø≈øels well provided, would have ≈øet upon them in the Haven, had not the Governour forbid it, telling them that they ≈øhould not fight under his no≈øe, but if they loved quarreling ≈øo well let them out and try their Fortunes in the open Sea, which they did accordingly, the manner of Seafights in tho≈øe days before the thundering Ordnance was found out, being only for one Ve≈ø≈øel to run again≈øt another, ≈øo that the the Ships were both Guns and Bullets them≈øelves. In which fight the Venetians prevailed, de≈øtroying near thirty of the Genoans Ships, and forcing the re≈øt to ≈øave them≈øelves in the Haven of Tyre.

Whereupon entering Ptolemais they expelled all the Genoans out of the City, pulled down their Buildings and plundered all their Shops, and Warehou≈øes, but after a ten years War they were at la≈øt reconciled in Pale≈øtine, by the Authority of Pope Clement the fourth, tho' their War la≈øted longer in Italy.

Charles Duke of Anjou, and Brother to King Lewis, was now made King of Sicily and Jeru≈øalem, by the Pope upon condition that he ≈øhould conquer Maufred, who then Reigned in Sicily, and Mole≈øted
His Holine≈øs, and root out all the remaining Race of Frederick, and as an acknowledgment that he held tho≈øe Kingdoms from the Pope, pay him an annual pen≈øion of four (≈øome ≈øay forty) thou≈øand Pounds.

But having Conquered Maufred and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of Sicily, he ≈øo little minded the regaining of Jeru≈øalem, that he never looked after it or came there at all, which neglect gave an opportunity to Hugh King of Cyprus to furbi≈øh up his old Title to that Kingdom as Linealy de≈øcended from Almerick the ≈øecond, who coming to Ptolemais was there Crowned King of Jeru≈øalem.

However the Chri≈øtians affairs in Syria began now to ha≈øten to their fatal Cata≈øtrophe, and the Kingdom of Jeru≈øalem was in a little time between two Kings wholly lo≈øt, for Haalon the Tartarian Prince being ≈øent for home to Succeed his Brother Mango, who died without I≈ø≈øue, left Abaga his Son with ≈øufficient forces in the City of Dama≈øcus, which he had likewi≈øe wan from the Turks, who following his Father, ≈øoon after ≈øub≈øtituted Guirboca his Lieutenant in Dama≈øcus, who having his Nephew ra≈øhly ≈ølain, by the Christians in an unhapy Broil about parting a great Booty taken from the Turks; wholly renounced
the Chri≈øtian Religion, together with all the Tartarians under his Command, ≈øo that the Kingdom of Jeru≈øalem having lo≈øt its be≈øt ≈øupport, ≈øoon after tumbled down.

Bondocdar who Succeeded Melechem in Egypt, taking advantage of their being thus de≈øerted by the Tartars, took the City of Joppa, all the inhabitants whereof he either killed; or which was wor≈øe, forced them to for≈øwear their Religion, and then marching to Antioch took that likewi≈øe, ≈ølaying twenty, and carrying away an hundred, thou≈øand Chri≈øtians, tho' it is to be ≈øu≈øpected that the number of the Captives were at fir≈øt written in figures, and in time increa≈øed ≈øome thou≈øands by the addition of nothing, after which he laid ≈øeige to Ptolemais it ≈øelf.

Tho≈øe woful tidings brought into Europe, ≈øo wrought on the good di≈øpo≈øition of King Lewis, that he re≈øolved upon a ≈øecond Voyage to Palestine, from which all the per≈øwa≈øions of his Nobles could no way divert him, in which Voyage there went with him his two Sons, Philip and Tri≈øtram, Theobald King of Navarre, his Son in law, Guido Earl of Flanders, and Prince Edward elde≈øt Son of Henry King of England, who was attended by his Brother Edmund, Earl ≈øurnamed Crouchback,
not becau≈øe he was crook-≈øhouldered, as was pretended by Henry Duke of Lanca≈øter, when he u≈øurped King Richard's Throne, but from his being a Croi≈øed Soldier in the Holy War.

Lewis being now on his way to Pale≈øtine, it was concluded by the general con≈øent of his Council, That for ≈øecuring the Christians pa≈ø≈øage to Syria, they ≈øhould fir≈øt take the City of Carthage in Affrica, or rather Tunis, which being rai≈øed out of the Ruins of that famous City, was now become a Ne≈øt of Pirates, who had killed and taken captive many Pilgrims, who were ≈øailing that way to the Holy Land. But no ≈øooner was the Siege began than the Plague ≈øeized on the Chri≈øtian Army, whereof Thou≈øands died, and among the re≈øt, Tri≈øtram, King Lewis's Son, and he him≈øelf of a Flux ≈øoon followed after. His lo≈øs was much lamented, he being accounted the French Jo≈øia, as well for the Piety of his Life, as the Wofulne≈øs of his Death, and his wilful ingaging him≈øelf in a needle≈øs and unfortunate War.
But notwith≈øtanding this Mortality, the Siege was continued, and Tunis brought into ≈øuch di≈øtre≈øs, that they were glad to ≈øurrender the Town on the≈øe Conditions:
That it ≈øhould pay yearly to Charles, King of Sicily and Jeru≈øalem, the Sum of Forty Thou≈øand Crowns.
That they ≈øhould receive Chri≈øtian Mini≈øters freely to Exerci≈øe their Religion.

p.hi: And that they ≈øhould be at the whole charge of that Voyage.

div.p:
Prince Edward would have had the Town beaten down and all the Inhabitants put to the Sword, accounting the foule≈øt Quarter too fair for ≈øuch Villains, and their Goods ≈øacrificed as an Anathema to God and burnt to a≈øhes, becau≈øe gotten by Robbery. But ≈øeeing he could not prevail with others, he re≈øolved however to ≈øhew his own dete≈øtation, by execrating his part of the Spoil, and cau≈øing it to be burnt, forbidding the Engli≈øh Soldiers to ≈øave any thing of it, telling them, that Coals ≈øtolen out of that Fire, would ≈øooner burn their Hou≈øes than warm their Hands. It troubled not the con≈øcience of other Princes however, to inrich them≈øelves therewith and glut them≈øelves with the ≈øtolen Honey found in that Hive of Drones: And not only ≈øo, but terminated their Pilgrimage there too, refu≈øing to proceed any further therein. Whereat Edward a≈øtoni≈øhed, ≈øtruck his Hands on his Brea≈øt, and ≈øwore,
That tho' they all for≈øook him, yet he would enter Ptolemais, if accompanied with Fowin his Hor≈øe-keeper only. And accordingly he arrived ≈øafe there, to the great comfort of the Chri≈øtians, who were in ≈øore di≈øtre≈øs. Whil≈øt Theobald, King of Navarre, with the Queen, and the Earl of Flanders, died in their way home, and mo≈øt of the Spoil was ca≈øt away.

At his arrival at Ptolemis, he found the Chri≈øtians ju≈øt lo≈øing their la≈øt ≈øtake, Bondocdar having brought them to ≈øo low an ebb, that they had re≈øolved if ≈øome unexpected Succour rever≈øed not their intentions, within three days to re≈øign it up. But Edward's coming in the interim, revived their hopes, and made them take Courage both to de≈øie their Enemies and their own thoughts of ≈øurrendring the City. Having ≈øufficiently victualed and manned Ptolemais, he marched with Six or Seven Thou≈øand Men to Nazareth, which he took, and ≈ølew tho≈øe he found therein. And being afterwards informed, that the Turks were gathered together at Cakhow, about Forty Miles from thence, he marched thither, and ≈øetting upon them early in the Morning, ≈ølew a Thou≈øand of them, and put the re≈øt to flight. In which Battel, as well as in ≈øeveral other Skirmi≈øhes, he gave
≈øufficient proof of his own per≈øonal Valour, ≈ølaying many of the Infidels in ≈øingle combat.

After this Victory he returned to Ptolemais, where Elenor his Con≈øort was delivered of a fair Daugher, but the Joy occa≈øioned thereby was ≈øoon turned into Sorrow, by the apprehen≈øion of his being mortally wounded by one of the A≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øines, who re≈øorting to him ≈øeveral times with Letters and Me≈ø≈øages from the Admiral of Joppa, who pretended a de≈øire to turn Chri≈øtian. The fir≈øt time of his coming, as the Prince was lying on his Bed and reading the Letters he brought, none being in the Room but them two, he ≈øuddenly ≈øtruck him into the Arm with an invenomed Knife, and attempted to have fetched another blow; but the Prince, who≈øe Valour was now awakened, gave him ≈øuch a blow with his Foot, that he felled him to the ground, and wre≈øting the poy≈øoned Knife out of his hand, thru≈øt it into the Murtherer's Belly and ≈ølew him; yet ≈øo that he hurt him≈øelf therewith in the Fore-head. It is ≈øtoried, that his Lady ≈øucked out all the venom of his Wounds, without prejudicing her ≈øelf. But however, certain it is, that by the help of Phy≈øick, good Attendance, and an Antidote, the Ma≈øter of the Templars gave him, he ≈øhewed him≈øelf
on Hor≈øe back ≈øafe and well within fifteen days after.

The Admiral hearing of his recovery, ≈øolemnly di≈øavowed his having any hand in the Treachery, it being ≈øeldom known that any will own them≈øelves the Parent of an un≈øucceeding Villany. And having done as much and more than could have been expected from ≈øo ≈ømall a number as he had with him, he returned home full fraught with Honour: And his Father, King Henry, being dead, the Engli≈øh Nobility met him as far as the Alpes, to attend him in his return home.

div.head: CHAP. IX.

argument.p: Rodulphus the Emperour hindred from going into Pale≈øtine, ≈øends the Duke of Mechlenburg. Charles King of Jeru≈øalem prevented in his intended Voyage.

div.p:
MUch talk there was now in Syria of the great preparations of Rodulphus, who was after two and twenty years Interregnum, cho≈øen Emperour of Germany, and though but a meer Earl of Ha≈øpurg, yet being now advanced to the Emperial
dignity, layed the fir≈øt foundation of the An≈øtrian Family, but he was too much imployed at home by Civil Di≈øcords, and reducing the Princes to obedience, who≈øe Knees were too ≈øtiff to do him Homage, till he had rendered them more pliable by degrees, to think of going into Syria.

But yet being ≈øomewhat unwilling to render their great expectations wholly fru≈øtrat, he ≈øent the Duke of Mechlenburgh with a good Army to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Christians, who coming to Ptolemais made ≈øeveral ≈øuccesful incur≈øions into the Enemies Countries about Dama≈øcus, de≈øtroying all before him with fire and ≈øword, and carying away many rich booties, till at la≈øt he was circumvented and taken pri≈øoner by the Mammalukes, who kept him in Captivity twenty ≈øix years, till at length the Sultan of Egypt a Runegado German, who had formerly been Enginneer to this Dukes Father, ≈øet him at Liberty together with Martin his Servant, thinking it but rea≈øonable, that he who had been his Partner in Mi≈øery ≈øhould likewi≈øe pertake of his Happine≈øs; but they were no ≈øooner at Liberty, but they were both took again by Pirats, as they were ≈øailing into Syria, which the Sultan hearing of pittied the misfortune of that di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Prince, and ≈øcorning that any ≈øhould
fru≈øtrate his de≈øigned courte≈øie, ≈øet him free once more, and then returning home he was welcomed with as much wonder as joy by his Subjects, who ≈øuppo≈øed him to have been dead long before.

When he came home he found two Counterfeits, who both pretended to be the Duke, and challenged lodging with his Lady; but upon his arrival to confute their fal≈øe pretences they were both condemned to lo≈øe their lives, by two contrary deaths, the one being Burn'd, and the other Drowned.

Charles King of Sicily and Jeru≈øalem, having at length made great preparations for the Holy War, and ≈øtrengthned his claim to the Kingdom of Jeru≈øalem, by purcha≈øing the Title of Maria, Domicella Prince≈øs of Antioch, who likewi≈øe pretended to a Right, he ≈øent Roger Count of Severine as his Vice-Roy to Ptolemais where he was received with a great deal of Honour in de≈øpite of King Hugh, but when his Navy and all things were ≈øaid to be ready for his own departure, and that he had by the way a de≈øign upon Michael Paleologus the Grecian Emperour, a ≈øudden and unexpected accident bla≈øted all,

For on Ea≈øter-day as the Bell tolled to Even-Song all the Frenchmen in Sicily had their Throats Cut, in a moment by the
Natives, the contriver of this Ma≈ø≈øacre was one, Jacobus Prochyta a Doctor of Phy≈øick, who thereby killed more in an hour then he cured in his Whole Life; but the ≈øecre≈øie of its contrivance vvas litle le≈øs then a Miracle, that ≈øo many ≈øhould knovv of it, and yet none either through accident or de≈øign di≈øcover it, from vvhence came the Proverb the Sicilian Vi≈øpers.

Charles him≈øelf was at Rome when this Tragedy was acted, to ≈øee the Pope make Cardinals, and when he received the news it ≈øtruck him ≈øo to the Heart that he never injoyed him≈øelf after; But living as without Life for about two years he died and left his Son Charles to Succeed him in the Kingdom of Naples, and the Title of Jeru≈øalem, who had little remarkable in his Life, but only that being offended with the Templars in Palestine, for taking part with the King of Cyprus again≈øt him, he ≈øie≈øed all the Lands, and Goods they had in Naples, or any other part of his dominions.

div.head: CHAP. X.

argument.p: Ptolemais Be≈øieged and taken by the Sultan of Egypt, and thereby the Holy War ended.

div.p:
MElech≈øaites or as others call him Melechme≈ø≈øor, about this time wan
the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Mergarh, from the Ho≈øpitallers, who kept it and bani≈øhed the Carmalites out of Syria, becau≈øe they had changed their Habits, at the appointment of Pope Honorious; the Turks being generally haters of innovations.

And Alphir who was his next Succe≈ø≈øor, under≈øtanding that the Chri≈øtian Princes of Europe were at variance among them≈øelves, re≈øolved to lay hold of that opportunity as the fite≈øt time finally to expel the Christians out of Palestine, and therefore coming out of Egypt with a great Army, he be≈øieged and won the Cities of Tripoli, Sidon, and Berytus, and being incouraged with this Succe≈øs, he adventured to Be≈øiege Tyre it ≈øelf and notwith≈øtanding its invincible ≈øtrength, took it in a very ≈øhort time, and beat it down to the ground as he did the other three Cities.

So that now there remained nothing of all that the Christians had won in Pale≈øtine, but Ptolemais, which he might ea≈øily have taken, if he would have ≈øate down before with his Army, but he was unwilling to venture for fear, lea≈øt if he ≈øhould attempt the taking all from them at once, he might thereby alarum the Christian Princes to repair thither for their Relief; and therefore concluded a Peace with the Venetians for five years, thinking that the bitter potion would be the more ea≈øily
≈øwallowed by them, if it were devided into two do≈øes.

But tho' the City Ptolemais did at this time e≈øcape the Turks Victorious Arms' yet it was notwith≈øtanding in a mo≈øt Wofull and Di≈ømal condition, for there were in it ≈øome of all Countrys, and every Nation had their ≈øeveral Courts, to de≈øide cau≈øes in; ≈øo that the great plenty of Judges occa≈øiond a ≈øcarcity of Ju≈øtice, and Malefactors when they were impeached for any Crime, would by appealing to a Tryal in the Court of their own Country: e≈øcape the de≈øerved Puni≈øhment, it being a ≈øufficient proof of the Criminals innocency in the Venetians, or Genoans Court, to ≈øay, that he was a Subject of the State, to which the Court belonged; wherefore Per≈øonal Crimes were made National, and particular faults by being e≈øpou≈øed, rendered publick offences, ≈øo that outrages were every where practi≈øed, and no where puni≈øhed, as if they had been re≈øolved to ≈øpare Divine Vengance the pains of overtaking them, by going forth to meet it.

Be≈øides which there was at this time a great number of Pretenders, eagerly pro, ≈øecuting their ≈øeveral Titles to that City being no fewer then the Venetians, Genoans, Pi≈øans, Florentins, the King of Cyprus
and Sicily, the Agents of the King of England and France, the Princes of Tripoli and Antioch, the Patriarch of Jeru≈øalem, the Ma≈øter of the Templars and Ho≈øpitallers, and the Popes Legate, who would if he were now living think him≈øelf highly abu≈øed, in not being fir≈øt named. All which Pretenders did at once with much Heat and Violence, urge there Right to the Airy Title of the Kingdom of Jeru≈øalem; and the Command of that City, like Bees making the greate≈øt noi≈øe and Bwzzing, when they were ju≈øt ready to for≈øake the Hive.

There was within the City at this time many new Pilgrims, who were lately come thither out of Europe, five hundred whereof were of the Popes ≈øending, altho' he afterwards took no care for their Pay, for tho' he loved to ≈øee the Golden Tide flow into his Coffers, yet he could not indure to ≈øee it ebb again. But the ≈øoldiers being not paid re≈øolved according to their blunt but u≈øual cu≈øtom to pay them≈øelves, and therefore Marching out of the City Pillaged the Enemies Country, contrary to the Peace made with Alphir. The Turks demand ≈øatisfaction, which was not only denied by tho≈øe of Ptolomais, but their Emba≈ø≈øadors likewi≈øe abu≈øed.

Which ≈øo inraged Sultan Serapha (Alphir
being now dead) that he gathered together all his Forces, and ≈øat down before the City, with an Army of ≈øix hundred thou≈øand men ≈øay ≈øome Hi≈øtorians, tho' others make them not half the number, and concluding that that City was ≈øo great a purcha≈øe, that if once obtained it could not be too dearly bought, he re≈øolved to take it before he ≈øtirred from the place.

Peter Belvi≈øe Ma≈øter of the Templars, a Valiant and Couragious General, being made Governour of the City by the general con≈øent of tho≈øe within, he incouraged the Chri≈øtians to be Valiant, and play the Men and not like Prodigal Heirs part with the City for nothing, which co≈øt their Predece≈ø≈øors ≈øo much pains, and Blood to get, or at lea≈øtwi≈øe to make one Blaze of Valour before their Lamp expired, telling them, it would be a ≈øhame for them to ≈øhew their Friends their Faces, if they turned their Backs to their Enemies; and thefore exhorted them to fight it out manfully, that ≈øo if forced at la≈øt to ≈øurrender it they might rather be pittied for want of Fortune, then ju≈øtly blamed for lack of Valour. And the City being now to wre≈øtle its la≈øt fall, he ≈øtripped it of all things that were comber≈øom and unu≈øeful, for all the Women and Children
and the Men too that were either aged or feeble, and had Mouths to eat and no Arms to fight he ≈øent away, retaining only twelve thou≈øand, which he conceived enough to defend the place notwith≈øtanding the va≈øt number of the be≈øiegers.

The Sultan A≈ø≈øaulted the City divers times with great Fury, but was ≈øtill beaten back by the Chri≈øtians Artillery, and great numbers of the Turks killed, but in one of tho≈øe conflicts the undaunted Governour was unfortunately ≈ølain by a poy≈øoned Arrow; a lo≈øs above grieving for, and the greater becau≈øe irreparable, many indeed were ≈øtrong in de≈øiring the Honour, but all too weak to di≈øcharge the Office; ≈øo that the Chri≈øtians being devided among them≈øeves neglected to defend the City, imagining that if it ≈øhould be taken, yet every Nation would be able to defend its part in regard their buildings were all fortified within them≈øelves, which idle and dangerous fancy took off their thoughts from minding the publick good, and fixed them only on their own private ends.

The Turks at length taking the advantage of this Prepo≈øterous neglect, entred the City at a breach which they had made in the Wall, by undermining of it, thinking their work had then been done, tho'
they quickly found to their co≈øt that it was but ju≈øt begun, for to their a≈øtoni≈øhment and wonder, they found Ptolemais not a City but a great heap of Citys, as it were thrown together, the people of every Nation having ≈øo Fortified them≈øelves in their ≈øeveral Forts, that they didfrom thence Power forth whole vollies of ≈øhot upon the Turks, when they entered the Streets, which makes it a thing hardly to be paralell'd in Hi≈øtory, for a City to hold out ≈øo long after it was taken, for they bravely defended them≈øelves again≈øt the Whole Turki≈øh power for fifty days together, and after all the re≈øt were ≈øubdued the Knights Ho≈øpitallers who allways bore an implacable hatred to the Turks, maintained their Ca≈øtle near a month longer, but their unhappy devi≈øion rendering them unable to ≈øub≈øi≈øt long, they were at length mo≈øt of them ≈ølain, and the City wholy ≈øubdued by there numerous enemies.

However it was a Bloody Victory to the Conquerour, mo≈øt of tho≈øe who entered the City being burned with Fire, killed with Arrows, or Smothered by the fall of Towers, of the very Ruins being as it were greedy of revenge, killed tho≈øe who de≈øtroyed them.

Ptolemais being now taken the Sultan thought it a good penyworth, tho' it co≈øt
him ≈øo dear, and therefore to make ≈øure work and prevent all feuture occa≈øion of Ejecting ≈øuch ≈øturdy Tennants, Levelled it even with the Ground.

No fewer then an hundred thou≈øand Christians which were all the Latines that were left; fled at this time out of Pale≈øtine into Cyprus, where they were freely entertained by Henry King of that I≈øland and Jeru≈øalem, to his great co≈øt but greater commendation.

Five hundred Matrons and Virgins of Noble Blood, are by the Mirracle Monger of that age, ≈øaid to ≈øtand on the ≈øhore of Ptolemais, with all their rich Jewels & cry out with a lamentable voice for ≈øome body to Tran≈øport them from that dangerous place, proffering any Marriner that would undertake it all their Wealth for his pains, and that he ≈øhould cho≈øe out of them any one whom he be≈øt liked for a Wife, and that thereupon a certain Marriner came and Tran≈øported them all freely, Landing them ≈øafely in Cyprus. But when he was ≈øent for to receive his Hire, it could not by the ≈øtricte≈øt enquiry be ever learnt who this Marriner was, or what became of him afterwards.

The Ho≈øpitallers were forced for ha≈øt to leave their Trea≈øure behind them which they hid in a Vault, making it known
from time to time to their Succe≈ø≈øors. About three hundred years after it was fetch'd away by the Galleys of Malta.

Thus after an hundred thirty four years had this Holy War its final period, having been for continuance the longe≈øt, for Charges the mo≈øt expen≈øive, for Slaughter of Men the mo≈øt Bloody, for Pretence the mo≈øt Pious, and for the True Intent of it the mo≈øt Politick and Subtil that ever the World ≈øaw. And at this day the Turks to ≈øpare the Christians pains in going ≈øo far as Palestine, have done them the unwelcome courte≈øie, to come more then half the way to meet them, but yet it is to be hoped that if they lo≈øe Buda, which they cannot in all po≈ø≈øibility avoid, they will be wholly driven out of Europe, by the Victorious Arms of the Chri≈øtians; and that it will not be long before their va≈øt and overgrown Empire be finally ruined, and ≈øink under the Ponderous Weight of its own greatne≈øs, to which let all who love the name of Chri≈øt, ≈øay, Amen.

div.head: CHAP. XI.

argument.p: The Holy War revived again by the pre≈øent Emperor of Germany, and the King of Poland. With the Parallel between that and the former War.

div.p:
SInce the Holy War was ended there hath been ≈øome offers of Chri≈øtian Princes to revive it again. For Henry the Fourth King of England, towards the latter end of his Reign, purpo≈øed to have made a Voyage into Pale≈øtine, being told by ≈øome pretenders to the gift of Prophe≈øie, that he ≈øhould not die tell he had heard Ma≈øs in Jeru≈øalem, but Henry was deceived, and the Voyage prevented by his dying ≈øoon after in a Chamber in his own Palace, at We≈øtmin≈øter called by that name. And Charles the Eighth King of France after his return out of Italy, ≈øent a huffing Emba≈ø≈øage to our Henry the ≈øeventh, wherein he gave him to under≈øtand that he had re≈øolved to make a ≈øecond conque≈øt of Naples, with a de≈øign to make u≈øe of it as a bridge, to tran≈øport his Forces into Grecia, re≈øolving neither to ≈øpare blood nor trea≈øure, altho' it were to the imparing of his Crown, and di≈øpeopling of his Kingdom, till he had either ruined the Ottaman Empire,
or taken it in his way to Par adice, (meaning the City of Jeru≈øalem) but the French having had enough of the fir≈øt adventure for Naples, we never hear more of this threatned Voyage, to Jeru≈øalem which is thought to be propounded, only to amu≈øe Henry till Charles ≈øhould have performed ≈øome projects he had then on foot, in the Dukedom of Britain, which de≈øign being ≈øcented by our King he u≈øed him accordingly.

More Cordial was the de≈øign of James the Fourth of Scotland, Who being touched in con≈øcience for his Fathers death (which tho' he did not procure, yet he ≈øeemed to countenance by his pre≈øence) to expiate his Crime, intended a voyage to the Holy Land. In order whereunto he had prepared his Souldiers, and imparted his de≈øign to Forrein Princes, and had certainly gon had not other wars breaking out unexpectedly, and his own ≈øudden death prevented him.

Among tho≈øe Overtures, we find one ≈øaid to be really performed by William Lantgrave of He≈ø≈øe, who with only Ninety eight Noble-men and Earls in his Company, made a Holy Voyage into Palestine, which he performed in Seven Months time. And upon his return, brought away with him Forty ≈øix En≈øigns of Hor≈øe, which he had taken from the Turks, with the lo≈øs of one
Man only, and he not ≈ølain neither, but died at Cyprus in their return home. A Victory ≈øo ab≈øolute and bloodle≈øs to the Conquerour, that were it true it would admit no parallel; but the Voyage and Victory were both fictitious, being found only in Calvi≈øious, who quotes one Fab, an Hi≈øtorian no where to be met withal, for his Author; and the Chronology wherein it is recorded being Printed after the Author's death, it is mo≈øt probable, that tho≈øe to whom the care of Printing it was committed, found this ≈øtory in ≈øome Paper he had put in his Chronicle, and for the improbability of it, marked it to be Fabulous; which word in regard he had written it defectively with the three fir≈øt Letters only, they thought to have been ≈øome Hi≈øtorian who≈øe Name was Fab, and ≈øo in≈øerted it in the Chronicle it ≈øelf.

Ever ≈øince the huffing Emba≈ø≈øy of Charles, the French King, the Holy War hath, for any thing I can find to the contrary, been wholly laid a≈øleep till revived again by the pre≈øent Emperour of Germany, and John Sobieski, King of Poland, in the Year 1683. The occa≈øion whereof was briefly thus:

The Grand Seignior having by the per≈øua≈øions of Count Teckeley, ≈øent an huge Army under the leading of the Grand Vizier, to invade the Imperial Territories in
Hugaria; again≈øt which the Duke of Lorain, who then commanded the Emperours Forces there, being not able to make head, they de≈øtroyed all before them with Fire and Sword; and pa≈ø≈øing forward, ≈øat down before Vienna, the Imperial City of Germany, not doubting but that they ≈øhould with their va≈øt Army have quickly devoured that Important Place, and notwith≈øtanding its having been ever accounted the Bulwork of Chri≈øtendom, have added it to the re≈øt of the Ottoman Conque≈øt. The Emperour of Germany, and the King of Poland, ≈øeeing the ≈øad E≈øtate to which things were now like to be reduced, entered into a League offen≈øive and defen≈øive, and re≈øolved with their united Forces, to cha≈øti≈øe the Turk for that proud Attempt.

The Vizier's Army, wherewith he had now begirt Vienna, con≈øi≈øted of an Hundred and Fifty Thou≈øand Men, which were the very Flower of the Turki≈øh Soldiery, wherewith he made ≈øeveral fierce Attacks upon the City, which were carried on with all the Courage and Skill imaginable, and ≈øprang ≈øeveral Mines, whereby he did more mi≈øchief, than by his Batteries. Notwith≈øtanding which, the City, by the re≈øolution and encouragement of Count Starembergh, their undaunted Governor, bravely defended it ≈øelf from the
fourteenth of July, till the twelfth of the following September, when the Turks were Forced to rai≈øe the Siege, and retire with great di≈øorder into Hungaria, whither they were ≈øo clo≈øely per≈øued by the Victorious Chri≈øtians, that very few of that numerous Army e≈øcaped to carry the tidings, of their Overthrow to Con≈øtantinople. Va≈øt quantities of Provi≈øion and Amunition, above an hundred pieces of Cannon, two Hor≈øe Tayls, which the Turks allways u≈øe to hang out as a Denounciation of War, when ever they undertake any great expedition, all their Tents, which were above thirty thou≈øand in number, all the Enemies Baggage, together with the Viziers own Hor≈øe, and the Grand Seignors STANDARD, which was extraordinary Rich and Sumptuous, being curiou≈øly Embroidered with charactars of Gold and Silver, upon Green and Red Silk, were here taken by the Chri≈øtians, as Trophies of their Victory; the form and ≈øhape of the Standard you have here de≈øcribed in this figure. The Infidels receiving likwi≈øe at the ≈øame time ≈øeveral great overthrows by the Sieur Kiniski, General of the Co≈ø≈øacks who having ≈ølain about thirty thou≈øand Turks and Taratrs, entred the Country of Budziak de≈øtroying all before him, ≈ølaying an hundred thou≈øand of them, and taking the Cities of Bialogrod, and Ketin.

The Chri≈øtians incouraged by the≈øe Victories re≈øolved to per≈øue them, and drive the Turks quite out of Europe, in order whereunto after they had taken the City of Tytchin, and ≈øeveral other places which the Turks held in Upper Hungaria, the Duke of Lorraein inve≈øted Buda it ≈øelf with the greate≈øt part of the Imperial Army, Commanding Count Le≈ølie to Encamp with the re≈øt, about Virovitzie, on the Drave, to cover the Siege. This City is the ≈øtronge≈øt place the Turks injoy in Hungary, it being formerly the Metropolis of that Kingdom, where the Kings of Hungary kept their Courts, but being taken from the Chri≈øtians in the Year 1591. By Solyman the Magnificent, Emperor of the Turks; they have ever ≈øince made it the ≈øeat and con≈øtant re≈øidence of their Chief Ba≈ø≈øa, or Vice-Roy of that part of Hungary, which is ≈ø≈øpo≈ø≈øeed by them, ≈øo that it is very populous and rich. And being exceedingly well fortified with a ≈øtrong built Wall, and an Invincible Ca≈øtle, and having between 18 or 19 Thou≈øand Men in Gari≈øon, they have made a ≈øtout re≈øi≈øtance, and declared a re≈øolution to defend it to the la≈øt Man. Notwith≈øtanding which it is verily believed that it cannot hold out much longer, but the Turks mu≈øt be forced to ≈øurrender that City to the Emperor, after having injoyed it near an hundred years.

And that the Turk might be imployed on all ≈øides, the Venetians were invited likewi≈øe into this League again≈øt them, which they accepted of, and ≈øent out a brave fleet under the Command of their Generall Moro≈øini, to attack them at home, to whch Fleet the Pope and the Knights of Malta al≈øo joyned ≈øeveral of their Galleys, and ≈øo did the Duke of Tu≈øcany, making in all forty ≈øix Galleys, ≈øix Gallie≈ø≈øes, thirty three Men of War, twenty four Petaches, four Fire Ships, ≈øixteen Brigantines armed, and eighty two Galliots, on Board whereof they had an Army of twenty five thou≈øand Men or upwards.

Sancta Maria a ≈øtrong Fortre≈øs of great con≈øequence to the Turks, was the fir≈øt place that felt the force of their victorious Arms, which being quickly compelled to a ≈øurrender, they took their cour≈øe towardsd Lepanto. And General Mora≈øeni concluding it nece≈ø≈øary, for the maintaining the Conque≈øt of Sancta Maria, to po≈ø≈øe≈øs him≈øelf of Preve≈øe, a place of great importance in regard it is ≈øituated at the very entrance, and Commands the Gulf of Arta, re≈øolved to attempt it.

Wherefore having Commanded five Galleys and ≈øix Gallie≈ø≈øes, to approach towards the Ca≈øtles of Gomenizze, not far from Preve≈øe, thereby to amu≈øe the Turks and oblige them to devide their Troops, by ≈øending reinforcements thither, which ≈øucceeded accordingly. For Saban Ba≈ø≈ø√† Governour of Preve≈øe, believing the Ventians de≈øigned to attack tho≈øe Ca≈øtles, ≈øent thither the greate≈øt part of tho≈øe he had drawn together, for the ≈øecurity of
the Town. He brought his whole Fleet to an Anchor at the entrance of the Gulfe, and the next morning ordred Captain Menetta with twenty four Barks, and ≈øeveral Armed Brigantines to enter the Gulph, and land with part of the Forces under the Command of General Stra≈øoldo. The Turks who expected them to land where the Galleys had po≈øted them≈øelves, and had therefore imployed their Chief care on that ≈øide, now perceiving their error, immediately ≈øent away five hundred Spahees to charge them, but they having put them≈øelves into order of Battail, gave them ≈øo hot a welcome that many af them were ≈ølain, and the re≈øt fled in ≈øuch di≈øorder that they were mo≈øt of them cut off, before they could reach the Town. Then the Chri≈øtians advancing, and having without oppo≈øition po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of a Hill near the Town, the General ≈øent to ≈øummon it, but the Officer who cammanded it in the ab≈øence of the Governour, (who was then abroad at the Head of a party of Turks, to ob≈øerve the Chri≈øtians and fancied they dur≈øt not undertake the Siege of ≈øo ≈øtrong a place,) would not receive the Generals letter, but fired upon the Me≈ø≈øenger that carried it; Whereupon four pieces of Cannon and as many Mortars were landed, and being placed upon a Battery, the next day about three hundred Bombs were ≈øhot into the Town, which burnt ≈øeveral Hou≈øes, and before night all their Cannon were di≈ømounted, except one. The next day they Lodged them≈øelves in the Ditch, & began to undermine the great Tower, whereupon twenty Turks made a ≈øalley in the night, & ≈øurpri≈øed ≈øome of the Chri≈øtians, which did but whet the Chri≈øtians Valour, and make them carry on their works with the greater eagerne≈øs and ≈øpeed, notwith≈øtanding the Enemy plyed them very clo≈øe, with their ≈ømall ≈øhot. So that the Mine being ready and a con≈øiderable breach made in the Wall, order was
given for a general a≈øault, but the Turks unwilling to run that hazzard, hung out a white flag and ≈øent five of their Principals to treat with the General, about ≈øurrendering the place. Who demanded the ≈øame conditions that were granted to the gari≈øon of Sancta Maria, but the General would con≈øent to no other terms, then only to permit thirty of the mo≈øt con≈øiderable of them to march out with their arms, and baggage, and the re≈øt without arms, taking with them what they could carry, which the Turks were forced to ≈øubmit to, and leave the Town to the Conqerours. The Turks by the lo≈øs of this place, be≈øides the Town it ≈øelf lo≈øt above 100000 Crowns, which they got yearly by the Fi≈øhery.
This War may very well be parallel'd to the ≈øormer and as Ju≈øtly de≈øerves the Name of Holy.

Fir≈øt, becau≈øe in this War the Quarrel is between Chri≈øtians and Turks, as well as in that and the de≈øign of the Wariours, is to Check the ≈øpreading of the Mahometan Super≈øtition, as well as to put a ≈øtop to the progre≈øs of the Ottoman Arms.
Secondly, as the former was undertaken to wre≈øt from the Turks, what had been before injoyed by the Chri≈øtians, and free the Profe≈ø≈øors of Chr≈øtianity from the Yoak of Infidelity, ≈øo was this.

Thirdly, as the former had the ble≈ø≈øing of the Pope, and his Holine≈øs's Contribution of money, and men for the carrying of it on, ≈øo had this & therefore will without doubt be looked upon, by Succeeding ages, as an Holy and Religious War, which I hope will never have a Period, till Mahomets Tomb be tumbled down, and the Ottoman Empire overthrown.
